column1: 3 Cheap Industrial Stocks Primed to Ride an Infrastructure Boom`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/3-cheap-industrial-stocks-primed-225132753.html`2024-01-22 22:51:32`We’ve all seen the headlines – America’s infrastructure is falling apart
column2: bridges are crumbling
column3: and major roads are chock full of potholes. The government knows infrastructure has been neglected for decades. That’s why
column4: back in 2021
column5: legislators passed massive spending bills totaling around $3 trillion targeted mostly at infrastructure modernization projects.Now
column6: almost three years later
column7: that infrastructure boom has arrived. Those federal dollars are just starting to flow into roads
column8: bridges
column9: airports
column10: broadband internet
column11: the electrical grid
column12: and more. There’s much more cash to come over the next decade
column13: too. I believe we’re only witnessing the start of a massive
column14: decade-long infrastructure boom.Accordingly
column15: I think it’s a smart play to get into industrial and materials stocks tied to infrastructure before the boom really takes off. These companies will see surging demand
column16: juicy government contracts
column17: strong earnings
column18: and rising stock prices. And the best part? Many infrastructure-related stocks are still cheap
column19: despite the sector’s bright prospects. Let’s take a look at some of the best options in the market right now!InvestorPlace - Stock Market News
column20: Stock Advice & Trading TipsSource: Pavel Kapysh / Shutterstock.comAs one of the largest steel producers in North America
column21: Cleveland-Cliffs (NYSE:CLF) stands to benefit enormously from the coming infrastructure boom. After its unsuccessful $35 per share bid for U.S. Steel
column22: some investors grew skeptical about Cleveland-Cliffs’ growth prospects. But I believe the selloff is overdone. Cleveland-Cliffs remains a bargain buy
column23: given the expected surge in infrastructure spending over the next decade.Missing out on U.S. Steel was a blow in the battle to consolidate the American steel industry. However
column24: Cleveland-Cliffs already completed its pivotal acquisition of AK Steel in 2020
column25: establishing its firm foothold as a major supplier of infrastructure materials. Compared to steel peers
column26: Cleveland-Cliffs boasts industry-leading profitability metrics. Current valuations around 10-times forward earnings dramatically undervalue Cleveland-Cliffs’ earnings growth potential
column27: if infrastructure tailwinds gather steam.Infrastructure legislation promises more than $1 trillion in new public works projects over the next decade. As shovel-ready construction unfolds
column28: demand for steel products will accelerate rapidly. And while steel prices have settled back to pre-pandemic norms
column29: resurgent economic expansion could easily ignite the next supercycle. If so
column30: Cleveland-Cliffs’ depressed share price presents a compelling value opportunity for investors betting on an infrastructure boom.Source: ShutterstockBlending cutting-edge AI technology with cloud computing and advanced sensors
column31: Iteris (NASDAQ:ITI) delivers smart mobility infrastructure solutions to improve transportation efficiency. This company stands ready to capitalize on the infrastructure spending wave as roads
column32: vehicles
column33: and cities grow increasingly connected.Recent earnings results validate Iteris’s leading position at this lucrative intersection of technology and infrastructure. In Q3 2023
column34: Iteris’ total revenue jumped 11% year-over-year
column35: exceeding analyst targets. For the full year 2023
column36: analysts forecast an impressive 32% earnings per share surge on continued double-digit revenue expansion. Yet
column37: despite eye-popping growth metrics
column38: ITI stock still trades at a mere 18-times forward earnings. That’s remarkably cheap for a tech stock executing so well.As governments earmark billions to upgrade transportation networks
column39: demand appears rock-solid for Iteris’ AI-powered mobility infrastructure solutions. Its ClearMobility platform visualizes traffic patterns to optimize mobility infrastructure planning and maintenance. Expansive product offerings (like advanced video and radar sensors to monitor intersections of every size) position Iteris well to capture a sizable share of this high-growth market. At 1.15-times forward sales compared to +10% revenue growth
column40: ITI’s modest valuations seem disconnected from the company’s fundamentals.Source: JHVEPhoto / Shutterstock.comAnother software maker benefiting from the infrastructure boom
column41: Autodesk (NASDAQ:ADSK) has its staked its claim in design and engineering in industries like architecture
column42: construction
column43: and manufacturing. Autodesk helps professionals design and create anything imaginable through its digital design platforms. And with infrastructure spending set to balloon over the coming decade
column44: demand seems certain to accelerate for Autodesk’s large-scale project solutions.After trading range-bound near $200 per share for most of 2022 and 2023
column45: ADSK stock has staged an impressive breakout over recent months. Since November
column46: shares are up nearly 26%
column47: outperforming the S&P 500 and Nasdaq benchmark. And with momentum building ahead of swelling infrastructure tailwinds
column48: I believe ADSK stock looks poised to continue steep gains.At almost 10-times forward sales
column49: Autodesk hardly looks like a bargain on the surface. However
column50: the company’s current valuation looks plenty reasonable for a software business reinvesting heavily to stimulate growth in massive addressable markets. Consensus forecasts call for Autodesk’s sales to double by 2032 as infrastructure and construction activity scales dramatically higher. And profits should follow suit
column51: expected to nearly double over the next eight years.Applying the same price-to-earnings multiple on future earnings
column52: ADSK’s share price would double if growth materializes as projected. Considering Autodesk’s track record of surpassing estimates year after year
column53: the company’s risk/reward profile appears to be tilted firmly to the upside.Software companies usually trade at a premium
column54: but Autodesk checks all the right boxes for me. Trading at 33-times next year’s earnings barely reflects Autodesk’s long runway for above-market growth as infrastructure spending ramps into overdrive.On the date of publication

column1: 17 Best Augmented Reality Stocks To Invest In`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/17-best-augmented-reality-stocks-104426829.html`2024-01-21 10:44:26`"In this article
column2: we will take a detailed look at the 17 Best Augmented Reality Stocks To Invest In. For a quick overview of such stocks
column3: read our article 5 Best Augmented Reality Stocks To Invest In.Just a few years back analysts were calling augmented reality the next big thing and AR startups were attracting huge investments. But now the sole focus of VCs and investment firms remains AI and AR seems to have taken a back seat. Does that mean the AR and VR revolution everyone was talking about ended before even starting? Experts don't think so. In fact they believe the rise of generative AI has opened up new horizons for augmented reality technologies. A report by NSFlow said that integration of AI and augmented reality will help companies produce realistic digital worlds
column4: characters and artwork.The report said AI will be used in multi-sensory technologies
column5: including haptic gloves and devices that create immersive experiences. More and more companies are now seeing the potential the combo of AI and AR could unlock. In June 2023
column6: Meta Platforms announced that its Reality Labs would be pursuing augmented reality and immersive reality technologies. And in December 2023 the company said its Ray Ban smart glasses showed how people would use AI and AR in immersive reality products in the future.Apple's blockbuster spatial computing headset Vision Pro is also a manifestation of the killer AI+VR combo. The device combines AI and VR to develop a spatial operating system and a 3D user interface to give a realistic experience to its user.A technician wearing a head-mounted augmented reality headset examining a MEMS device.MethodologyFor this article we scanned Insider Monkey's database of 910 hedge funds and picked 17 augmented reality companies with the highest number of hedge funds. We preferred companies which make actual AR-related hardware and software products or develop technologies that are used by other companies in the development of augmented reality products. Hedge funds’ top 10 consensus stock picks outperformed the S&P 500 Index by more than 140 percentage points over the last 10 years (see the details here). That’s why we pay very close attention to this often-ignored indicatorNumber of Hedge Fund Investors: 3 Rochester

column73: Bonsai Partners stated the following regarding QUALCOMM Incorporated (NASDAQ:QCOM):“Robustness at the product level exists differently than in other layers of the value chain. Product diversification follows the same principle
column74: but product control isn’t related to vertical integration. Product control exists in multiple forms
column75: such as switching costs or happy customers who don’t want to buy elsewhere. However
column76: one often overlooked dimension of product-level robustness is adaptability. Some businesses offer goods and services that behave like shapeshifters; they naturally adapt to the market’s needs regardless of how the world changes. Adaptability also serves as a hedge against the unknown.Consider our investment in Taiwan Semiconductor
column77: which enjoys a highly adaptive product portfolio. If we compare TSMC to a fabless chip maker like QUALCOMM Incorporated (NASDAQ:QCOM)
column78: investing in Qualcomm is a bet that its products will retain their technological advantage over time. Meanwhile
column79: TSMC sells a service that naturally produces whatever the end customer wants. There is little need for brilliant product-level foresight; TSMC just needs to maintain its process and service level advantages
column80: allowing it to manufacture whatever the market demands. TSMC’s product portfolio is robust compared to most other semiconductor companies because it naturally adapts to technological and market-driven shifts. Instead of product-level risk
column81: TSMC’s core risks are geopolitical.In the past
column82: I would have been more drawn to a company like Qualcomm given its clear technological lead in baseband modems
column83: but if I’m honest with myself
column84: I don’t know if their technologies will retain their dominance ten years from now. Qualcomm’s products express a relatively high degree of rigidity in a fast-changing industry
column85: and this is something I prefer to avoid.While robustness isn’t a guarantee of company survival

column1: Estimating The Intrinsic Value Of Ameren Corporation (NYSE:AEE)`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/estimating-intrinsic-value-ameren-corporation-135356871.html`2024-01-17 13:53:56`Using the Dividend Discount Model
column2: Ameren fair value estimate is US$71.97Ameren's US$71.21 share price indicates it is trading at similar levels as its fair value estimate The US$77.00 analyst price target for AEE is 7.0% more than our estimate of fair valueToday we'll do a simple run through of a valuation method used to estimate the attractiveness of Ameren Corporation (NYSE:AEE) as an investment opportunity by taking the expected future cash flows and discounting them to today's value. One way to achieve this is by employing the Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) model. There's really not all that much to it
column3: even though it might appear quite complex.We generally believe that a company's value is the present value of all of the cash it will generate in the future. However
column4: a DCF is just one valuation metric among many
column5: and it is not without flaws. Anyone interested in learning a bit more about intrinsic value should have a read of the Simply Wall St analysis model. View our latest analysis for Ameren We have to calculate the value of Ameren slightly differently to other stocks because it is a integrated utilities company. Instead of using free cash flows
column6: which are hard to estimate and often not reported by analysts in this industry
column7: dividends per share (DPS) payments are used. This often underestimates the value of a stock
column8: but it can still be good as a comparison to competitors. The 'Gordon Growth Model' is used
column9: which simply assumes that dividend payments will continue to increase at a sustainable growth rate forever. For a number of reasons a very conservative growth rate is used that cannot exceed that of a company's Gross Domestic Product (GDP). In this case we used the 5-year average of the 10-year government bond yield (2.2%). The expected dividend per share is then discounted to today's value at a cost of equity of 6.2%. Relative to the current share price of US$71.2
column10: the company appears about fair value at a 1.1% discount to where the stock price trades currently. Valuations are imprecise instruments though
column11: rather like a telescope - move a few degrees and end up in a different galaxy. Do keep this in mind.Value Per Share = Expected Dividend Per Share / (Discount Rate - Perpetual Growth Rate)= US$2.9 / (6.2% – 2.2%)= US$72.0We would point out that the most important inputs to a discounted cash flow are the discount rate and of course the actual cash flows. If you don't agree with these result
column12: have a go at the calculation yourself and play with the assumptions. The DCF also does not consider the possible cyclicality of an industry
column13: or a company's future capital requirements
column14: so it does not give a full picture of a company's potential performance. Given that we are looking at Ameren as potential shareholders
column15: the cost of equity is used as the discount rate
column16: rather than the cost of capital (or weighted average cost of capital
column17: WACC) which accounts for debt. In this calculation we've used 6.2%
column18: which is based on a levered beta of 0.800. Beta is a measure of a stock's volatility
column19: compared to the market as a whole. We get our beta from the industry average beta of globally comparable companies
column20: with an imposed limit between 0.8 and 2.0
column21: which is a reasonable range for a stable business.StrengthEarnings growth over the past year exceeded the industry.Debt is well covered by earnings.WeaknessDividend is low compared to the top 25% of dividend payers in the Integrated Utilities market.OpportunityAnnual earnings are forecast to grow for the next 4 years.Good value based on P/E ratio and estimated fair value.ThreatDebt is not well covered by operating cash flow.Paying a dividend but company has no free cash flows.Annual earnings are forecast to grow slower than the American market.Although the valuation of a company is important
column22: it shouldn't be the only metric you look at when researching a company. DCF models are not the be-all and end-all of investment valuation. Preferably you'd apply different cases and assumptions and see how they would impact the company's valuation. If a company grows at a different rate
column23: or if its cost of equity or risk free rate changes sharply
column24: the output can look very different. For Ameren
column25: we've put together three important elements you should further research:Risks: Every company has them
column26: and we've spotted   2 warning signs for Ameren   (of which 1 is a bit concerning!) you should know about.Management:Have insiders been ramping up their shares to take advantage of the market's sentiment for AEE's future outlook? Check out our management and board analysis with insights on CEO compensation and governance factors.Other Solid Businesses: Low debt
column27: high returns on equity and good past performance are fundamental to a strong business. Why not explore our interactive list of stocks with solid business fundamentals to see if there are other companies you may not have considered!PS. The Simply Wall St app conducts a discounted cash flow valuation for every stock on the NYSE every day. If you want to find the calculation for other stocks just search here.Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content? Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively
column28: email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock

Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.Related Quotes`['AEE']`

column3: but the company still has a way to go before reaching its yearly highs again. With many analysts covering the large-cap stock
column4: we may expect any price-sensitive announcements have already been factored into the stock’s share price. But what if there is still an opportunity to buy? Let’s examine AES’s valuation and outlook in more detail to determine if there’s still a bargain opportunity. See our latest analysis for AES According to our valuation model
column5: the stock is currently overvalued by about 39%
column6: trading at US$16.50 compared to our intrinsic value of $11.91. This means that the buying opportunity has probably disappeared for now. If you like the stock
column7: you may want to keep an eye out for a potential price decline in the future. Since AES’s share price is quite volatile
column8: this could mean it can sink lower (or rise even further) in the future
column9: giving us another chance to invest. This is based on its high beta
column10: which is a good indicator for how much the stock moves relative to the rest of the market.Investors looking for growth in their portfolio may want to consider the prospects of a company before buying its shares. Buying a great company with a robust outlook at a cheap price is always a good investment
column11: so let’s also take a look at the company's future expectations. With revenues expected to grow by a double-digit 12% over the next couple of years
column12: the outlook is positive for AES. If the level of expenses is able to be maintained
column13: it looks like higher cash flow is on the cards for the stock
column14: which should feed into a higher share valuation.Are you a shareholder? AES’s optimistic future growth appears to have been factored into the current share price
column15: with shares trading above its fair value. At this current price
column16: shareholders may be asking a different question – should I sell? If you believe AES should trade below its current price
column17: selling high and buying it back up again when its price falls towards its real value can be profitable. But before you make this decision
column18: take a look at whether its fundamentals have changed.Are you a potential investor? If you’ve been keeping an eye on AES for a while
column19: now may not be the best time to enter into the stock. The price has surpassed its true value
column20: which means there’s no upside from mispricing. However
column21: the optimistic prospect is encouraging for AES
column22: which means it’s worth diving deeper into other factors in order to take advantage of the next price drop.Keep in mind
column23: when it comes to analysing a stock it's worth noting the risks involved. Every company has risks
column24: and we've spotted 2 warning signs for AES you should know about.If you are no longer interested in AES
column25: you can use our free platform to see our list of over 50 other stocks with a high growth potential.Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content? Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively
column26: email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. column1: 11 Stocks That Will Make You Rich in 5-10 Years`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/11-stocks-rich-5-10-120121544.html`2024-01-21 12:01:21`"In this article
column2: we will take a detailed look at the 11 Stocks That Will Make You Rich in 5-10 Years. For a quick overview of such stocks
column3: read our article 5 Stocks That Will Make You Rich in 5-10 Years.Can investing in stocks make you rich? This question is rarely posed anymore since data has overwhelmingly proved that investing in the stock markets is one of the best ways to increase your wealth over time. A report in October 2023 by the Wall Street Journal talked about the rise of ""mini-millionaires"" and how the average wealth of American families was increasing
column4: citing data from the Federal Reserve. Mini-millionaires usually make about $150
column6: 000 a year. The report said between 2019 and 2022 families in the 80th to 90th percentile of the income distribution saw the biggest rise in their incomes as their median wealth increased by about 69% from 2019 through 2022
column7: adjusted for inflation.The report said that over 90% of these families reported owning stocks
column8: either directly or indirectly.Needless to say
column9: investing in the stock market is full of crevices. You can't expect to get rich investing in low-quality stocks and random companies with no value. Investing in stocks to become rich involves patience
column10: wise choices and sticking to traditional investing principles. Legendary value investor Seth Klarman had in 2000 foreseen the changing trends in the stock market where investors were becoming impatient
column11: expecting to make money without paying attention to the actual fundamentals of companies. But Klarman at the time had also predicted the return of traditional methods of evaluating companies before investing. In his letter to investors Klarman had said:""If Paul Harvey's serialized radio program ""The Rest of the Story"" were applied to Wall Street
column12: it would describe the sad denouement of many such ""story"" stocks. The unraveling of the virtuous circle of growth is not pretty
column13: with earnings shortfalls
column14: plunging share prices
column15: employees with under-water options jumping ship
column16: overzealous shareholders receiving margin calls
column17: accounting chicanery exposed
column18: lawsuits filed
column19: and
column20: to come full circle
column21: the final insult of deletion from the relevant major market index. At this time
column22: attractive valuation is not considered a good story. A slow growth or no growth company trading at one half or one third of its underlying value attracts no important constituency of investors. I sometimes joke about the new market valuation rules of thumb: stocks that fail to meet earnings expectations all seem to trade at 10 times reduced earnings
column23: while formerly profitable companies that report losses all seem to trade at five dollars per share. Many investors avoid these stocks precisely because others are staying away. Why would those kind of stocks ever go up
column24: they wonder. Even those of us with value investing in our DNA generally prefer situations with catalysts for the realization of underlying value.Over time
column25: this will change. At some unknowable future point
column26: the undervaluation of small capitalization stocks lacking exciting growth characteristics will become so gaping that investors will once again be attracted. The point of investing
column27: after all
column28: is not to have a great story to tell; the point of investing is to make money with limited risk. At some point
column29: investors will drop their Pulitzer prize winning story stocks and revisit their attention on the old classics
column30: stocks that make you money because their undervaluation creates a compelling imbalance between risk and return.""Seth Klarman of Baupost GroupMethodologyFor this article we scoured various analyst reports and interviews to pick 11 stocks that experts believe can make one rich in the next 5-10 years.Number of Hedge Fund Investors: 16ChargePoint Holdings Inc (NYSE:CHPT) is one of the stocks that can make one rich in the next few years according to Wall Street analysts. Oppenheimer analyst Colin Rusch last year set a $27 price target on the stock. ChargePoint Holdings Inc (NYSE:CHPT) was trading at $2.11 as of January 4. Here is why the analyst likes the stock:“Of note
column31: in our view
column32: is that the company’s substantial product development cycle is slowing and management continues to expect material operating leverage as R&D spend moderates. Second
column33: demand continues to be robust as EV sales grow in multiple geographies driving charging infrastructure buildout. Third
column34: the company is well capitalized as it drives toward positive adjusted EBITDA in F2Y4 and manages working capital needs for growth. We remain constructive on shares as we anticipate the company will enjoy both top-line growth and margin expansion in coming quarters.”In addition to CHPT

column37: who also has a $43 price target on the stock

column39: according to TipRanks:“Commercially led by eye care veteran CCO Mottiwala (ex-VP Marketing Allergan Eye Care)
column40: TARS is well-positioned to develop a new category
column41: eyelid health. We are particularly encouraged by market research revealing an intent to prescribe for demodex blepharitis (DB) of 93%. As awareness grows

column1: AES Completes Construction of 3.5 GW of Renewables in 2023`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/aes-completes-construction-3-5-120000296.html`2024-01-18 12:00:00`"Construction Milestone Marks the Largest Renewables Capacity Addition by AES in a Single YearARLINGTON
column2: Va.
column3: Jan. 18
column4: 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- The AES Corporation (NYSE: AES) announced the completion of 3.5 GW of renewables projects in 2023
column5: nearly doubling the capacity constructed compared to 2022.""In 2023
column6: AES completed the construction of 3.5 GW of new renewables. This construction milestone represents a new record and a growth rate of nearly 100% over 2022. Including these newly added projects
column7: AES' portfolio of renewables now reaches 18.4 GW
column8: said Andrés Gluski
column9: AES President and Chief Executive Officer.Of the 3.5 GW of projects that AES completed
column10: 1.6 GW are solar
column11: 1.3 GW are wind and 0.6 GW are energy storage. Examples of notable projects completed in 2023 include:Great Cove Solar is a 220 MW project comprised of two solar facilities in Franklin and Fulton Counties
column12: Pennsylvania being commissioned in multiple phases. It is the largest solar project in the Commonwealth and the University of Pennsylvania will purchase all electricity produced at the sites. The project will generate enough energy to power 70% of the total electricity demand of Penn's academic campuses and the University of Pennsylvania Health System
column13: helping to support the University's goal of achieving a 100% carbon neutral campus by 2042. The project will also host a research study onsite in partnership with Penn's Environmental Innovations Initiative
column14: which could offer the industry insight on best practices for soil health management on operational solar projects.Chevelon Butte Wind is a 238 MW wind project
column15: and Phase 1 of a 454 MW wind facility in Coconino and Navajo counties
column16: Arizona. Once Phase 2 becomes operational this year
column17: collectively it will be the state's largest wind farm. The project is sited on the Chevelon Butte Ranch
column18: one of the oldest working cattle ranches in Arizona. The facility is compatible with existing livestock ranching and hunting land uses
column19: enabling the landowner family and Arizona State Land Department to continue the more than century-long tradition of raising livestock and stewarding the land.McFarland A Solar-plus-Storage is a 200 MW solar and 100 MW energy storage project located in Yuma County
column20: Arizona. As one of the largest solar-plus-storage projects in the state
column21: this facility represents the next generation of sustainable energy infrastructure powering a more secure and reliable electric grid. The project has already created hundreds of jobs in the region during construction.Oak Ridge Solar is a 200 MW solar facility located in Morehouse Parish
column22: Louisiana. Oak Ridge Solar is the largest operating solar project in the state and will provide low-cost electricity while reducing carbon emissions and generating economic benefits for the local Morehouse Parish community. This project not only represents a high-value economic investment in the region but also supports Louisiana solar energy growth.About AESThe AES Corporation (NYSE: AES) is a Fortune 500 global energy company accelerating the future of energy. column642: which remains flat.Definitions of Oil and Gas ReservesReserves are estimated remaining quantities of crude oil and natural gas and related substances anticipated to be recoverable from known accumulations
column644: based on the analysis of drilling
column647: and engineering data; the use of established technology; and specified economic conditions
column648: which are generally accepted as being reasonable. Reserves are classified according to the degree of certainty associated with the estimates as follows:Proved Reserves are those reserves that can be estimated with a high degree of certainty to be recoverable. It is likely that the actual remaining quantities recovered will exceed the estimated proved reserves.Probable Reserves are those additional reserves that are less certain to be recovered than proved reserves. It is equally likely that the actual remaining quantities recovered will be greater or less than the sum of the estimated proved plus probable reserves.Information Regarding Disclosure on Crude Oil and Natural Gas Reserves and Operational InformationIn accordance with Canadian practice

column662: and account for drilling locations that have associated contingent resources based on a best estimate of such contingent resources. PR drilling locations are derived from the GLJ Resource Report
column663: and account for drilling locations that have associated prospective resources based on a best estimate of such prospective resources. Of the roughly 6
column670: 275 are PR locations. Contingent resources are those quantities of petroleum estimated
column672: to be potentially recoverable from known accumulations using established technology or technology under development
column673: but which are not currently considered to be commercially recoverable due to one or more contingencies. Prospective resources are those quantities of petroleum estimated
column675: to be potentially recoverable from undiscovered accumulations by application of future development projects. Prospective resources have both an associated chance of discovery and a chance of development. Prospective Resources are further subdivided in accordance with the level of certainty associated with recoverable estimates assuming their discovery and development and may be subclassified based on project maturity. Economic contingent resources are those contingent resources that are currently economically recoverable. The sub-classes included under economic contingent resources are Development Pending CR
column677: and Development Unclarified CR. Development Pending are resources where resolution of the final conditions for development is being actively pursued (high chance of development). Development on Hold are resources where there is a reasonable chance of development but there are major non-technical contingencies to be resolved that are usually beyond the control of the operator. Development Unclarified are resources where the evaluation is incomplete and there is ongoing activity to resolve any risks or uncertainties. Development Not Viable are resources that are not viable in the conditions prevailing at the effective date of the evaluation
column678: and where no further data acquisition or evaluation is currently planned and hence there is a low chance of development.There is no certainty that ARC will drill all drilling locations and if drilled there is no certainty that such locations will result in additional oil and gas production. The drilling locations on which ARC will drill wells will ultimately depend upon the availability of capital
column684: additional reservoir information that is obtained and other factors.This news release contains estimates of the NPV of the Company's future net revenue from reserves associated with ARC's assets. column5: Inc. (Nasdaq: AEMD)

The replay conference ID number is 7691190.About Aethlon and the Hemopurifier®Aethlon Medical is a medical therapeutic company focused on developing the Hemopurifier
column17: a clinical stage immunotherapeutic device which is designed to combat cancer and life-threatening viral infections and for use in organ transplantation. In human studies
column18: the Hemopurifier has demonstrated the removal of life-threatening viruses and harmful exosomes from blood utilizing its proprietary lectin-based technology. This action has potential applications in cancer
column19: where exosomes may promote immune suppression and metastasis

column21: and with cancer types in which exosomes have been shown to participate in the development or severity of the disease. The Hemopurifier also holds an FDA Breakthrough Device designation and an open Investigational Device Exemption (IDE) application related to the treatment of life-threatening viruses that are not addressed with approved therapies.Additional information can be found at www.AethlonMedical.com.Forward Looking StatementsThis press release contains forward-looking statements within the meaning of Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 that involve risks and uncertainties. column1: Is Weakness In ARC Resources Ltd. (TSE:ARX) Stock A Sign That The Market Could be Wrong Given Its Strong Financial Prospects?`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/weakness-arc-resources-ltd-tse-134832281.html`2024-01-20 13:48:32`"With its stock down 8.7% over the past three months
column2: it is easy to disregard ARC Resources (TSE:ARX). However
column3: stock prices are usually driven by a company’s financial performance over the long term
column4: which in this case looks quite promising. Particularly
column5: we will be paying attention to ARC Resources' ROE today.Return on Equity or ROE is a test of how effectively a company is growing its value and managing investors’ money. In simpler terms
column6: it measures the profitability of a company in relation to shareholder's equity. View our latest analysis for ARC Resources Return on equity can be calculated by using the formula:Return on Equity = Net Profit (from continuing operations) ÷ Shareholders' EquitySo
column7: based on the above formula
column8: the ROE for ARC Resources is:26% = CA$1.8b ÷ CA$7.1b (Based on the trailing twelve months to September 2023).The 'return' refers to a company's earnings over the last year. One way to conceptualize this is that for each CA$1 of shareholders' capital it has
column9: the company made CA$0.26 in profit.So far
column10: we've learned that ROE is a measure of a company's profitability. Depending on how much of these profits the company reinvests or ""retains""
column11: and how effectively it does so
column12: we are then able to assess a company’s earnings growth potential. Assuming everything else remains unchanged
column13: the higher the ROE and profit retention
column14: the higher the growth rate of a company compared to companies that don't necessarily bear these characteristics.Firstly
column15: we acknowledge that ARC Resources has a significantly high ROE. Second
column16: a comparison with the average ROE reported by the industry of 17% also doesn't go unnoticed by us. As a result
column17: ARC Resources' exceptional 63% net income growth seen over the past five years
column18: doesn't come as a surprise.We then compared ARC Resources' net income growth with the industry and we're pleased to see that the company's growth figure is higher when compared with the industry which has a growth rate of 42% in the same 5-year period.Earnings growth is a huge factor in stock valuation. The investor should try to establish if the expected growth or decline in earnings
column19: whichever the case may be
column20: is priced in. This then helps them determine if the stock is placed for a bright or bleak future. Is ARX fairly valued? This infographic on the company's intrinsic value has everything you need to know.ARC Resources' ' three-year median payout ratio is on the lower side at 19% implying that it is retaining a higher percentage (81%) of its profits. So it looks like ARC Resources is reinvesting profits heavily to grow its business
column21: which shows in its earnings growth.Moreover
column22: ARC Resources is determined to keep sharing its profits with shareholders which we infer from its long history of paying a dividend for at least ten years. Based on the latest analysts' estimates
column23: we found that the company's future payout ratio over the next three years is expected to hold steady at 19%. Still
column24: forecasts suggest that ARC Resources' future ROE will drop to 18% even though the the company's payout ratio is not expected to change by much.In total
column25: we are pretty happy with ARC Resources' performance. Specifically
column26: we like that the company is reinvesting a huge chunk of its profits at a high rate of return. This of course has caused the company to see substantial growth in its earnings. With that said
column27: on studying the latest analyst forecasts
column28: we found that while the company has seen growth in its past earnings
column29: analysts expect its future earnings to shrink. To know more about the latest analysts predictions for the company
column30: check out this visualization of analyst forecasts for the company.Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content? Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively
column31: email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock
column32: and does not take account of your objectives
column33: or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.Related Quotes"`['AETUF']`

column124: we would expect net earned premiums in 2024 to decline 2.5% to 1.5%. When taking into consideration
column125: the impact of reinsurance
column126: paid-up policies and the deferred profit liability reclassification.Adjusted net investment income increased 4% to JPY 365.6 billion
column127: as we experienced higher yields on our U.S. dollar-denominated investments and related favorable FX. This was partially offset by transfer of assets due to reinsurance. Pretax earnings were JPY 456.9 billion or 6% higher than a year ago.For 2024
column128: we would expect our well-priced in-force to show greater stability in terms of the benefit ratio
column129: excluding unlockings and to be in the range of 66% to 68%. This is a function of both favorable morbidity experience and improved mix of business.With the current trend in revenues
column130: we're actively reducing our expenses. We are taking both tactical efforts as well as more long-term transformational initiatives
column131: and we would expect our expense ratio to be in the range of 19% to 21% going forward.The pretax profit margin for Japan for 2023 was 30.5%
column133: a very good result. With approximately 30% of the Japan portfolio in U.S. dollar assets
column134: the strength of the U.S. dollar versus the yen has increased the proportion of net investment income as a component of our pretax profit. With a greater contribution to profitability from net investment income in yen terms
column135: our pretax margin is naturally pushed up. In addition
column136: having transitioned to option-based currency hedging
column137: we expect quarterly hedge costs to remain roughly in line with what we experienced in the fourth quarter of 2023. In combination with a lower expected benefit ratio
column138: we expect a pretax profit margin of 29% to 31% in 2024.Turning to Aflac U.S. Our 2023 total benefit ratio came in well below expectations at 42.8%. We estimate that the remeasurement gains impacted the benefit ratio by 500 basis points in 2023. Claims utilization has stabilized. But as we incorporate more recent experience into our reserve models
column139: we unlocked assumptions and released reserves during the year.Persistency increased 130 basis points year-over-year to 78.6%. This is a function of poor persistency quarters following out of the metric and stabilization across numerous product categories.Our expense ratio in the U.S. was 40.6%
column140: up 90 basis points year-over-year
column141: primarily driven by our growth initiatives and higher DAC amortization. We would expect the U.S. expense ratio to decrease over time as these businesses grow to scale and improve their profitability.For the full year
column142: total adjusted revenues were up 2.1% to $6.6 billion. Net earned premiums increased 1.9% to $5.7 billion in 2023. Adjusted net investment income increased 8.6% to $820 million
column143: mainly driven by higher yields on both our fixed and floating rate portfolios.Pretax earnings were $1.5 billion or 10.4% higher than a year ago
column144: driven primarily by the lower benefit ratio
column145: which was largely impacted by the third quarter unlock and only partially offset by the higher expense ratio.For 2024
column146: we would expect net earned premium growth to be in the range of 3% to 5%.Profitability for the U.S. segment was solid
column147: with a pretax margin of 22.7%
column148: driven primarily by the remeasurement gains from unlocking.Looking forward at 2024
column149: as we grow products with a higher benefit ratio and lower expense ratio
column150: like group life and disability and network dental and vision
column151: you should start to see those changes reflected in our ratios over time. In 2024
column152: we would expect to operate with a benefit ratio in the range of 45% to 47%
column153: and an expense ratio of 38% to 40%. This translates into an expected profit margin of 19% to 21%.In our Corporate segment
column154: we recorded a pretax loss of $425 million
column155: compared to a loss of $218 million a year ago
column156: primarily due to higher investment tax credits and the impact of the innovation of our reinsurance treaty with a third party.Adjusted net investment income was $54 million lower than last year due to an increased volume of tax credit investments. Higher rates began to earn in and amortized hedge income increased. This tax credit investments impacted the corporate net investment income line for U.S. GAAP purposes negatively by $343 million
column157: with an associated credit to the tax line.The net impact to our bottom line was a positive $39 million. To date
column158: these investments are performing well and in line with expectations. The impact from the reinsurance innovation was a onetime negative of $151 million.Overall
column159: we are very pleased with our 2023 results and our outlook for 2024. I'll now turn the call back to David
column160: so we can begin Q&A. David?David YoungThank you
column162: we will now take the first question.Operator(Operator Instructions) The first question today comes from Tom Gallagher with Evercore ISI.Thomas George GallagherOne numbers question and then one on strategy.Just the numbers question. I guess for the last several years
column163: you've had better portfolio yield in Japan being driven by to pivot into USD portfolio. If I look at the last couple of quarters
column164: that seems to be flattening out. So your portfolio yield has been more stable. Can you talk about what's driving that and what it means for 2024 NII in Japan? And then
column167: just given the growth headwinds in Japan
column168: would you guys consider anything more meaningful on M&A strategically to help facilitate growth? I know you haven't really done this in the past
column169: but there does seem to be an element of kind of unavoidable demographic headwind in Japan that you're fighting against here. So curious what you think on strategy there.Max Kristian BrodenI'll kick it off and then hand over to Brad and then to Dan for the strategy question.As it relates to our investment portfolio and net investment income
column170: you're correct in noticing that our net investment income has increased over the last couple of years. A portion of that is driven by our increased allocation to U.S. dollar assets. And I do want to remind you that
column171: that is primarily driven by the view that we have of hedging our economic exposure to the yen as it relates to the overall exposure that we have as a company to the yen throughout like Japan.We have now reached what we view to be more of a steady state as it relates to our total U.S. dollar allocation. So from that level
column172: I would expect a stabilization in terms of our total allocation between yen and dollars within the investment portfolio.But as it relates to more of an outlook into 2024 for our NII
column173: I'll turn to Brad and he can give you some more color.Bradley Eugene DyslinYes. The only thing I would add is just to remind you that our new money yield is both a blend of lower yen rates as well as the higher U.S. dollar rates. Most of our deployment is planned for U.S. dollar assets and that is to maintain the balances
column174: as Max just described. But we do still like yen spread products when we can locate acceptable outlets. When that happens
column175: then we will put them in the portfolio and that does result in pulling down the overall reported new money yield just because of the simple math of lower yen rates.Daniel Paul AmosAnd Tom
column177: that's been an issue we've had for several years. We feel like that one of the things we are addressing (technical difficulty) cancer or medical product to it by starting them off on an inexpensive savings plan that gets them to participate with us.We also continue to look for new product. We have still not found that third product or third leg that we want to find. And we're continuing to try things.But I don't know of anyone right now that I would trade places within Japan in terms of distribution and product that we have and believe we can continue to grow our business moving forward. Saying that
column178: we have to be realistic that it is an aging population and it also is a position where it's not the population is declining.But all in all
column179: I still believe it's the best market in the country or in the world because of the persistency and our ability to continue to grow it. And so I think you're going to see growth for the next several years. We did lower that number to -- from JPY 80 billion just to be cautious
column180: but we're encouraged.Our Japan Post growth and what's gone there continues to do very well
column181: and we've enjoyed our relationship there. It's our existing distribution system that was really hurt
column182: both in the U.S. and Japan
column184: but more so in Japan because if you look back at COVID
column185: it really lasted an additional year in Japan. And because our agents are commission-driven
column188: all of a sudden did not have an opportunity to go out and sell one-on-one. And as we've always said
column190: they're not bought. And so we go out and make those presentations
column191: and we couldn't do it.And so people that were normally working for us on a commission basis tried to find other jobs that were salary in nature and that's what we've been fighting
column192: but it is coming back both in the U.S. and Japan
column193: and I'm encouraged by what I'm seeing there.OperatorThe next question comes from Suneet Kamath with Jefferies.Suneet Laxman L. KamathJust a couple on Japan. And the first one
column195: just gets back to something you're just talking about in terms of the JPY 67 billion to JPY 73 billion sort of target down from the JPY 80 billion. Are you viewing that as sort of just a delay? And that
column196: that JPY 80 billion is ultimately achievable
column197: maybe a year beyond your original target? Just -- I wanted to think about it a little bit longer term.Daniel Paul AmosWell
column198: I certainly think it's the potential out there. I don't know what year because the COVID with such an anomaly
column199: what I'd like to do is to let our people that are there on the -- Koide or whoever wants to take this particular question can do it. And then I'll follow up if there's any other part you want me to directly address.Masatoshi KoideYes. This is Koide
column200: Aflac Japan.[Interpreted] So let me answer the question.And the reason why we've changed our target from JPY 80 billion to JPY 67 billion to JPY 73 billion was because we knew that it would take a longer time. So we do think that we are able to achieve JPY 80 billion if we look beyond 2026 or after.Suneet Laxman L. KamathGot it. Okay. All right. And then I just had another question on
column202: persistency in Japan. If I just think back to Aflac from years ago
column203: it strikes me that part of the reason the persistency was so strong is because you sold at the work site and there just was very little job mobility in Japan so people just kept the products for a long time. And I guess the question is
column204: as you're shifting now to new distribution channels outside of the work site and to a younger population
column205: which seems to be the objective
column206: should we just expect a natural decline in that persistency over time?Max Kristian BrodenI'll kick it off and I'll let anybody add some commentary to that as well. As we sell to younger customers
column207: that should actually improve the persistency because of the age-based pricing that we have in Japan
column208: there's a very strong incentive to hold on to the product for a long time and maybe even for life. So as you sell into a younger population
column209: that tends to reduce your lapse rates and improve your persistency.Suneet
column210: you are correct to -- when you look at the corporate agencies that you are referring to from the past that
column211: that was -- had very strong persistency overall in that channel. And as that has become a smaller piece of our overall inforce
column212: that have structurally reduced our persistency.The other thing I would mention as well is that we have seen an aging of the block. And when you have an aging of the block
column213: that naturally leads to higher lapsation and lower persistency as well. So you hear us talk about that we are trying to reach younger customers
column214: that is partially to sort of fight these sort of long-term trends that we have going on in our inforce block to not only provide coverage and new coverages to the younger population
column215: but also to improve the overall persistency of the block.All of this is marginal from year-to-year
column217: but it's certainly something that we're watching closely.Daniel Paul AmosYoshizumi
column218: do you have any comments you'd like to add? Our head of sales in Japan.Koichiro Yoshizumi[Interpreted] This is Yoshizumi. And regarding the persistency that was just asked and answered by Max
column220: by us focusing on young and middle-aged customers
column221: our persistency is going to be higher
column222: and that is our strategy. And that is actually represented by the medical insurance that was just launched on September 19.And this product is very popular among the young and middle-aged customers whose ages are under 49 or 49 and under.In terms of the number of policy count that we sold to these young and middle-aged customers
column223: we actually saw a 46% increase year-on-year from the time that we launched in September to the end of the year last year. And these customers are for our middle and long-term growth of Aflac Japan
column224: and these are the customers who will be our assets and our treasure going forward.And the actual premiums that are being paid by young and middle-aged customers are lower. And we truly believe that by focusing on these younger customers and increasing these young customers would contribute to stable growth of our company. And at the same time
column226: the persistency rate will be higher and this is our strategy.Daniel Paul AmosI just want to remind you all that the persistency rate is really high. And we can move it up a little bit
column228: but it is more than we ever dreamed when we first started doing business over there. So we're very pleased with it. So -- but at the same time
column229: we will improve because when you're writing younger people
column233: will be more persistent.OperatorThe next question comes from Jimmy Bhullar with JPMorgan.Jamminder Singh BhullarSo first
column234: a question on Japan. And if you think really long term
column235: is it even realistic to assume that the business can grow given that the population shrinking
column236: the population is aging as well? And then versus 10
column238: there are a lot more companies in the product lines that you're in? So if you could just comment on that
column239: like -- and maybe on your -- the reduction in guidance on sales
column240: how much of that has to do with just Japan taking longer to recover from COVID versus some of these demographic headwinds?Daniel Paul AmosWell
column242: you're correct in terms of a competitive environment. But what is in Japan or any other country that isn't competitive. So being competitive is nothing new to us
column243: and something that we are understanding that we have to constantly look for ways to address how we can identify with consumers and show the need for our products even more.Now don't forget
column244: we've seen copays and deductibles over many years. I don't know when another one will take place or what will happen. But as inflation
column246: you have to take that into account
column248: our ability to convert and add more premium to existing policyholders always makes a difference and grows our block of business as well
column249: and we especially think that with the younger people. Let me now turn to Japan and let them comment on it.Masatoshi KoideYes. This is Koide
column250: Aflac Japan.[Interpreted] And it is true that Japan is being projected as having declining population. But at the same time
column251: with the advancement of longevity in the 100-year life era
column252: the need to prepare for longevity risk is expected to increase steadily.And it's also expected that the aging population could increase the medical cost because as you live long
column253: the probability of suffering from cancer and other diseases will increase.And in Japan
column254: the sustainability of the overall social security system is being discussed. And this would also include medical and nursing care. And this is being questioned
column255: and the discussions are underway within the Japanese government to review how the benefits and burden should be balanced.And given these circumstances
column256: there is a way of thinking about helping themselves or self-help and preparing for the future as people become more aware of the situation. And as a result
column258: we do think that the third sector market will steadily grow going forward as well.Jamminder Singh BhullarOkay. And then on the U.S. business
column259: do you have a better clarity on the tri-agency rule and its potential impact on your sales?Virgil Raynard MillerThis is Virgil
column260: good morning from the U.S. We have been working with the tri-agency sales to talk about any potential impact we could see to those selling supplemental into the consumers out there. And we're waiting on a ruling. Thus far
column261: they set a date to be on April 2024
column262: you know and I know that a date may move. However
column263: we remain encouraged that our policies and coverages are relevant regardless if that rule does come through.We looked at our (inaudible) sales from last year. We really didn't see any decline. We remain flat there. And again
column265: even if there is a rule or not a rule
column266: our coverage is relevant and we're not predicting any major impact going forward.OperatorThe next question comes from Wilma Burdis with Raymond James.Wilma Carter Jackson BurdisCould you talk a little bit about the outlook for capital generation
column267: and if we should expect anything on an ongoing basis from internal reinsurance opportunities?Max Kristian BrodenWilma
column268: if you think about the total capital generation that we've had recently and also going into 2024
column269: I don't see any significant change to our overall capital generation on an organic basis. That remains in the $2.6 billion to $3 billion range. On top of that
column270: we know that we have opportunities that we can overtime unlock more capital through utilizing our reinsurance platform
column271: and we intend to do so. We can't necessarily predict exactly when that will happen or what amounts that will be
column272: but you've seen us in the recent past be quite active on that front. So I would expect us to do more. But on a pure
column273: sort of run rate organic basis
column274: I would have pegged our underlying capital generation at $2.6 billion to $3 billion annually.Wilma Carter Jackson BurdisAnd could you just talk more about the commercial real estate watch list? It's higher than a lot of the peers
column275: and you guys have taken the key back on a few properties lately. So if you could go into that and what you're seeing there?Unidentified Company RepresentativeSure. I think there's one primary thing related to our watch list relative to our portfolio that makes us different than peers
column276: and that's the fact that the bulk of our exposure is in transitional real estate. Remember
column277: that's a much shorter asset class. It's a much shorter maturity
column278: generally a 3-year term with some options to extend out a fourth and fifth year.So because of that
column279: when you have a market downturn and you've got these maturities coming due and the liquidity is as poor as we're seeing in the market today
column280: it naturally creates an elevated watch list and creates an elevated amount of potential foreclosures. Now
column281: we work very closely with our borrowers to address those maturities. We do our best to avoid foreclosure. But if they are not willing to work with us
column282: if they're not willing to reset the loan to reflect current valuations and give us other protections
column283: we are fortunate that we're in a position we can and will foreclose if we think that's the best route to maximize our recoveries. We are blessed with a strong capital and liquidity position
column284: which prevents us from being a forced seller here. So I think it's a combination of the nature of our portfolio
column285: having shorter maturities relative to our total exposure. And then the fact that we are much more willing to foreclose and able to foreclose
column286: if we think that's the best route.OperatorThe next question comes from Elyse Greenspan with Wells Fargo.Elyse Beth GreenspanMy first question
column287: going back to just Japan sales guidance. Dan
column288: I know you said you guys are being cautious in lowering the outlook there. But how do we think about -- how should we think about going from the JPY 60.7 billion of sales in '23 to the new JPY 67 billion to JPY 73 billion target? Should we think about that being even -- even over the next few years or maybe a bit more back-ended?Daniel Paul AmosJapan? Okay. Well
column289: we at this particular time are just evaluating what we think might happen for the next 2 years. And frankly
column290: we've just tried to be conservative and give us some latitude on what would happen. But we have some very positive things coming out in 2024 that we think will drive sales and are encouraged about it and even some things as we're looking to 2025 that will be coming.Let me make sure that Koide or -- they don't want to make any comments in that regard. Koide?Koichiro YoshizumiYes. This is Yoshizumi.Daniel Paul AmosOkay
column291: Yoshizumi.Koichiro Yoshizumi[Interpreted] Okay. Let me answer the question.And as Dan mentioned earlier
column292: it is true that COVID has impacted Japan way beyond our expectation. And as a result
column293: the number of solicitors or sales agents have decreased significantly. And even if you were -- even if our agencies are able to hire the sales agents
column294: we were not able to train them.It was not until May last year in Japan that COVID has been reclassified at the same level as with influenza. So we had no choice
column295: but faced really truly difficult situation in sales for a long time. And at the same time
column296: it is also true that it took us quite a bit of time to train those sales agents that have lower skill. But right now
column297: what we are very much focused on is to really recruit and train that the solicitors or sales agents. Otherwise
column298: we will not be able to train and grow those sales agents that are customer-centric.Aflac sales agents must be those agents that are very welcomed by our customers. What I mean by that is that those sales agents must respond to customers' needs when they solicit policies
column300: when the benefits and claims are paid. And I do believe that it is Aflac's mission to send out these kind of sales agents to the market appropriately. And that is the reason why we have set our sales target relatively conservative. And we currently do have recruiting and development and training plan for our future
column302: beyond maybe JPY 80 billion or even more in the future.Max Kristian BrodenElyse
column303: I would think about the sales trajectory as being relatively linear
column305: not back-end loaded.Elyse Beth GreenspanThat's helpful
column306: Max. And then my second question
column308: you obviously have a good amount of buffer at the holdco relative to where you've talked about running. How do you think about
column310: managing that down? And how should we think about the level of potential buybacks in '24?Max Kristian BrodenSo we're obviously operating with a very significant capital levels in all of our subsidiaries at the moment. Over time
column311: I would expect us to operate at slightly lower capital levels in terms of the ratios than where we are today.I would reflect that in Japan
column312: we are now going through a transition from SMR to ESR. So I wouldn't necessarily make any dramatic changes ahead of that. In the U.S.
column315: target in an RBC of closer to 400%
column316: and we have active plans towards drawing that down.At the same time
column317: we have strong capital and liquidity at the holding companies. We always think about where is capital serving us the best at that very point in time
column319: making sure that we have capital available for deployment into dividends
column322: I would say that our capital plans remain solid. We've got plenty of capital around
column323: and we try to place it where it makes the best use.OperatorYour next question comes from John B. Barnidge from Piper Sandler.John Bakewell BarnidgeI had a question of going back to the Japan sales target. I know you put out a press release in December about the Trupanion pet insurance partnership for Japan. Did that pivot remove any sales contribution from the JPY 80 billion assumption? And can you talk...Daniel Paul AmosNo
column324: it did not.John Bakewell BarnidgeOkay. Then can you maybe talk about the growth opportunity for that product in the U.S. that was called out in the pivot and commitment to ownership stake?Max Kristian BrodenPet insurance
column326: has a significant opportunity in the U.S. market because of the very low penetration of the product itself.For Aflac
column327: we act as a distributor where these premiums
column330: do not hit our income statement. So it's an opportunity to -- for our distribution to earn additional commissions
column332: it's very positive to Aflac.We do
column334: have an alliance and a partnership with Trupanion that is strong through the equity ownership that we have in the company
column335: and we capture significant economics over time through that equity ownership.OperatorYour next question comes from Joel Hurwitz with Dowling & Partners.Joel HurwitzFirst
column336: a question on U.S. expenses. So the outlook looks to be largely in line with prior year. You've talked in the past on bending the expense curve and getting closer to a mid-30% expense ratio. Can you just provide an update on those expectations and when we should start to see a more significant drop in the expense ratio in the U.S.?Max Kristian BrodenSo you are starting to see a drop in 2024
column337: and I would expect that to continue. There are 2 forces at play here
column338: both expenses and our revenues. Expenses
column339: we have active plans to improve our expense efficiency and reduce expenses
column340: both from a tactical and transformational standpoint. But also do not disregard the impact from revenues here. So as we have a number of businesses that are not at scale today
column341: they will grow to scale. And when they do that
column342: their expense ratios will drop significantly
column343: and that will improve overall our expense ratio
column345: push that down.The last piece to all of this is also where is our future growth coming from. It is generally coming from low expense ratio businesses. Predominantly
column346: the group life and disability business that operates at a significantly lower structural expense ratio than the voluntary benefits business.So if you take all of that together
column347: we should have a trajectory that is going lower and we would expect to operate in the 35% to 37% over time.Joel HurwitzOkay. Makes sense. And then just on the recapture. Any color on the economic benefit? And then are there other blocks that you could potentially execute something similar on?Max Kristian BrodenSo overall
column348: we're very pleased with the economics. The -- in terms of the impact on future run rate results
column350: but they're obviously favorable. So there's a favorable run rate going forward. In terms of the other blocks out there
column351: I do deem that this is -- was the one that we really had out there. I wish we had more than we could do
column352: but this was really the one that we had outstanding.OperatorThe next question comes from Ryan Krueger with KBW.Ryan Joel KruegerFirst
column353: I just wanted to follow up on the U.S. expense ratio
column354: given that the group products also tend to have higher benefit ratio. So just curious
column355: as you continue -- as you do grow those business lines and the expense ratio comes down
column358: for the margins in the U.S. is to increase? Or to what extent would that be offset by naturally higher benefit ratios on those products?Max Kristian BrodenSo I think that we have been in a structurally low benefit ratio period
column360: I would expect our benefit ratios to increase. And you're right
column362: to acknowledge that the mix impact will also push our benefit ratios higher. So we're always going to see that mix impact
column363: impacting both expense ratio and benefit ratios going forward. And that will have a slightly negative impact to the pretax margin going forward because of mix.I'll kick it over to Virgil Miller to give his comments as well.Virgil Raynard MillerSo first
column364: we're not pleased where we sit with the expense ratio. That is absolutely a focus for the U.S. And one of the things we're doing is making sure we have plans that are going to continue to be in that curve
column365: and you'll see that happening over a period of time. And we're basically challenging all of the U.S. leadership to be accountable for that
column366: and it is tied to our little compensation. Now I'll go step further
column368: I mentioned that when we talked about the actual sales growth this year
column369: one of the things we mentioned -- you heard Dan mention earlier
column370: is our strong underwriting discipline. We are making sure that we only put policies and business on the books that actually have better persistency and lower turnover rates with employees.So the underwriting discipline itself will continue to help drive and bend that expense curve and drive up that benefit ratio
column373: the continued growth that we're seeing on (inaudible)
column374: it would change the overall business mix in the U.S. So just to conclude
column375: it is absolutely a focus for us and that we are confident we've got the right plans in place to start bidding that curve starting next year.Ryan Joel KruegerAnd then on Japan internal reinsurance
column376: you've done a transaction 2 years in a row. Is there any practical limitation on doing something like that kind of pretty regularly? Or is there anything that would commit your ability to do that?Max Kristian BrodenSo Ryan
column378: we would expect that we could see at about 10% of the Aflac Japan balance sheet to Aflac Bermuda. There are no real legal limitations to it
column380: we got to acknowledge any sort of risks associated with internal reinsurance to make sure that we don't overexpose ourselves or we make sure that we can handle everything associated with it. So over time
column381: I would expect us to see something like 10%. And to date
column382: we have done about 4%.Virgil Raynard MillerAnd this is Virgil. Let me just go back to add
column383: when I was talking about being on that curve
column385: in 2024. I just want to make sure you got that. I said next year
column386: but I mean 2024.OperatorThe next question comes from Josh Shanker with Bank of America.Joshua David ShankerJust a question as to whether or not the yen at JPY 140
column388: does that change your hedging costs
column389: your desire to hedge the strategy at all in your investment portfolio?Unidentified Company RepresentativeSo obviously
column390: the pricing of options will move and that impacts to some extent
column391: the cost of hedging. And so obviously
column392: every input that you would have to the pricing of options would impact that. In terms of the level of the yen
column393: the answer is no. We want to structurally protect the economic exposure we have to the yen. And we do that through the dollar allocation that we have in the general account. We do that through the debt that we issue in yen
column394: and we do that through the forwards that we hold at the holding company
column397: we do this in order to reduce risk
column398: not necessarily to express an opinion on the yen. Now
column399: how we hedge and protect ourselves
column400: we have all these different levers that we can pull
column401: and the cost and return on capital associated with those can vary over time because of the capital markets. So that's why we will then dial up and dial down some of those associated with that. But it's not necessarily associated with the level of the yen-dollar rate. We are not FX traders. We're looking to protect ourselves long term.OperatorThis concludes our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the conference back over to David Young for any closing remarks.David YoungThank you
column403: and thank you all for joining us this morning. If you have any additional questions
column404: please reach out to the Investor and Rating Agency Relations team. We will be happy to talk to you then
column405: and we look forward to speaking to you soon. Have a great day.OperatorThe conference has now concluded. Thank you for attending today's presentation. You may now disconnect. AGNC Investment Corp. Declares Monthly Common Stock Dividend of $0.12 per Common Share for February 2024`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/agnc-investment-corp-declares-monthly-210100047.html`2024-02-08 21:01:00`BETHESDA
column2: Md.
column3: Feb. 8
column4: 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- AGNC Investment Corp. (Nasdaq: AGNC) announced today that its Board of Directors has declared a cash dividend of $0.12 per share of common stock for February 2024. The dividend is payable on March 11
column5: 2024 to common stockholders of record as of February 29

column1: Corebridge Financial (CRBG) Earnings Expected to Grow: Should You Buy?`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/corebridge-financial-crbg-earnings-expected-150053333.html`2024-02-08 15:00:53`Corebridge Financial (CRBG) is expected to deliver a year-over-year increase in earnings on higher revenues when it reports results for the quarter ended December 2023. This widely-known consensus outlook gives a good sense of the company's earnings picture
column2: but how the actual results compare to these estimates is a powerful factor that could impact its near-term stock price.The stock might move higher if these key numbers top expectations in the upcoming earnings report
column3: which is expected to be released on February 15. On the other hand
column4: if they miss
column5: the stock may move lower.While the sustainability of the immediate price change and future earnings expectations will mostly depend on management's discussion of business conditions on the earnings call
column6: it's worth handicapping the probability of a positive EPS surprise.Zacks Consensus EstimateThis financial services company is expected to post quarterly earnings of $0.99 per share in its upcoming report
column7: which represents a year-over-year change of +12.5%.Revenues are expected to be $5.42 billion
column8: up 1.4% from the year-ago quarter.Estimate Revisions TrendThe consensus EPS estimate for the quarter has been revised 0.18% lower over the last 30 days to the current level. This is essentially a reflection of how the covering analysts have collectively reassessed their initial estimates over this period.Investors should keep in mind that an aggregate change may not always reflect the direction of estimate revisions by each of the covering analysts.Earnings WhisperEstimate revisions ahead of a company's earnings release offer clues to the business conditions for the period whose results are coming out. Our proprietary surprise prediction model -- the Zacks Earnings ESP (Expected Surprise Prediction) -- has this insight at its core.The Zacks Earnings ESP compares the Most Accurate Estimate to the Zacks Consensus Estimate for the quarter; the Most Accurate Estimate is a more recent version of the Zacks Consensus EPS estimate. The idea here is that analysts revising their estimates right before an earnings release have the latest information
column9: which could potentially be more accurate than what they and others contributing to the consensus had predicted earlier.Thus
column10: a positive or negative Earnings ESP reading theoretically indicates the likely deviation of the actual earnings from the consensus estimate. However
column11: the model's predictive power is significant for positive ESP readings only.A positive Earnings ESP is a strong predictor of an earnings beat
column12: particularly when combined with a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy)
column13: 2 (Buy) or 3 (Hold). Our research shows that stocks with this combination produce a positive surprise nearly 70% of the time
column14: and a solid Zacks Rank actually increases the predictive power of Earnings ESP.Please note that a negative Earnings ESP reading is not indicative of an earnings miss. Our research shows that it is difficult to predict an earnings beat with any degree of confidence for stocks with negative Earnings ESP readings and/or Zacks Rank of 4 (Sell) or 5 (Strong Sell).How Have the Numbers Shaped Up for Corebridge?For Corebridge
column15: the Most Accurate Estimate is lower than the Zacks Consensus Estimate
column16: suggesting that analysts have recently become bearish on the company's earnings prospects. This has resulted in an Earnings ESP of -0.78%.On the other hand
column17: the stock currently carries a Zacks Rank of #3.So
column18: this combination makes it difficult to conclusively predict that Corebridge will beat the consensus EPS estimate.Does Earnings Surprise History Hold Any Clue?While calculating estimates for a company's future earnings
column19: analysts often consider to what extent it has been able to match past consensus estimates. So
column20: it's worth taking a look at the surprise history for gauging its influence on the upcoming number.For the last reported quarter
column21: it was expected that Corebridge would post earnings of $1.06 per share when it actually produced earnings of $1.05
column22: delivering a surprise of -0.94%.Over the last four quarters
column23: the company has beaten consensus EPS estimates three times.Bottom LineAn earnings beat or miss may not be the sole basis for a stock moving higher or lower. Many stocks end up losing ground despite an earnings beat due to other factors that disappoint investors. Similarly
column24: unforeseen catalysts help a number of stocks gain despite an earnings miss.That said
column25: betting on stocks that are expected to beat earnings expectations does increase the odds of success. This is why it's worth checking a company's Earnings ESP and Zacks Rank ahead of its quarterly release. Make sure to utilize our Earnings ESP Filter to uncover the best stocks to buy or sell before they've reported.Corebridge doesn't appear a compelling earnings-beat candidate. However
column26: investors should pay attention to other factors too for betting on this stock or staying away from it ahead of its earnings release.Expected Results of an Industry PlayerAnother stock from the Zacks Insurance - Multi line industry
