I thought what I would do is spend my time and provide a little bit of historical perspective and road map as to where we're going.We've just come back from our partners retreat
column50: where all 201 Apollo partners get together and we discuss the outlook. And I began those remarks by anchoring people in history. In 2008
column51: we were $44 billion of AUM. You fast forward. We've grown 14x. That's faster than Apple's revenue. That's faster than Microsoft's revenue. That's faster than semiconductors
column52: truly extraordinary. I'd like to think that was all as a result of management acumen and management positioning
column53: but we are the beneficiary of macro industry factors that drove not just us but our entire industry. Dodd-Frank; substantial money printing; for excess return in a low rate environment; and the commoditization of debt and equity markets
column54: public markets
column55: through indexation and correlation were the powerful tailwinds that drove our industry and allowed us to grow 14x.Some of these factors are still here
column56: but I have to say the factors that are going to drive us going forward are different than the factors that in fact got us to 2023. As I think about the big drivers of our business
column57: first
column58: I think there is a fundamental rethink going on as to the difference between public and private. Most of us have grown up in an investment world where private was risky and public was safe. We had a private allocation
column59: an alternatives bucket
column60: illiquid allocation. And it was generally a relatively small portion of an institution or an individual's total strategic asset allocation and with good reason. Private
column61: at least in the old days
column62: was risky. Private equity
column63: venture capital and hedge funds dominated the private bucket.On the other hand
column64: public was perceived as safe. Stocks and bonds 60-40 portfolio world where public is both safe and risky and private is safe and risky; and the difference is only a matter of liquidity. I believe we are going to see a substantial pivot from institutions where they begin to think about private not just in a traditional alternatives context
column65: but they think about private as just another investment that has a little less liquidity. And the question they'll be asking is
column66: ""Am I being compensated for slightly less liquidity?"" I think that is nothing but a positive for our industry and for our firm. The second is this continued commoditization of public market returns. We are at an extreme of indexation and concentration and correlation.Not just between debt and equity markets
column67: but so much of our equity market is dominated by a handful of companies that -- with outsized valuations and outsized PE that really do drive the public indices. While that's going up
column68: that feels great. That can just as easily go in the other direction. Sophisticated investors
column69: institutional and individual
column70: understand this. And if they are seeking to separate themselves from the beta of the public markets and look for alpha
column71: they will need to look for other solutions other than those in the public markets and through indexation. High net worth and the entry of individual investors into the private markets and alternatives. We are in the earliest early days of this. This hasn't even started. This is a $65 trillion market that ultimately has the potential for private markets investors such as ourselves and our peer group to be as large
column72: if not larger than

column75: but the level of understanding of how private investments can be incorporated into these portfolios is very

column77: some $12 trillion in 401(k). These are the people in our country who need returns the most
column78: and we force them to be daily liquid for 50 years. Why? I don't know why. I don't think there's a good reason why. And we're beginning to see cracks even in the 401(k) market of an allocation to private

column80: but again I think this is a very powerful trend that bodes well for our firm and for our industry.Finally

column3: 2024 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Apollo (NYSE: APO) today announced that industry veteran Harry Seekings has been named Co-Head of Infrastructure at Apollo
column4: effective March 11
column5: 2024. Seekings will work alongside Olivia Wassenaar
column6: Head of Sustainability and Infrastructure.Apollo Co-President Scott Kleinman said
column7: “We are pleased that Harry will join Apollo as Co-Head of Infrastructure. With over 25 years of industry experience
column8: Harry has a proven track record and tested ability to grow and manage transnational teams
column9: and we believe he will play an integral role in driving the continued growth of our Infrastructure franchise. We continue to see compelling opportunities to invest in infrastructure assets

column11: expertise and capital markets capabilities to provide value for companies.”Seekings said
column12: “Apollo operates one of the industry’s leading mid-market Infrastructure franchises

column15: and I look forward to working with the team to build on the strong progress underway.”Apollo’s Infrastructure franchise has a deep bench of talent including seven partners and 25 investment professionals dedicated to the strategy. The team focuses on mid-market businesses and assets

column17: digital infrastructure
column18: global supply chain and sustainable living.Seekings joins Apollo from InfraRed Capital Partners where he held several leadership roles

column21: New York and Sydney. Prior to this

column23: University of Cambridge and a Master of Arts with Honors in Modern History from Jesus College
column24: University of Oxford.About ApolloApollo is a high-growth
column25: global alternative asset manager. In our asset management business

column32: creative
column33: and knowledgeable approach to investing aligns our clients
column34: businesses we invest in
column35: our employees
column36: and the communities we impact

column13: operator. Good morning and thank you to those of you joining us on the Apollo Commercial Real Estate Finance fourth quarter 2023 earnings call. I am joined as usual today by Scott Weiner

column16: the start of 2024 feels very much like where we were at the start of 2023 for the commercial real estate sector. If you recall
column17: entering 2023
column18: there was significant negative sentiment concerning commercial real estate
column19: fueled by concerns over the impact of elevated interest rates on valuations and pending debt maturities
column20: uncertainty on the long-term use case for office properties and a lot of consensus with respect to both the path of the economy and the future trajectory of interest rates.The Fed continuing to raise rates in the first half of 2023 and the notable volatility in the 10-year treasury rates further added to the concern and uncertainty in the market. In addition
column21: the failure of several notable regional banks
column22: coupled with increased reserves and negative commentary from money center banks regarding their real estate portfolios further added to the generally pessimistic perspective. While there were some notable transactions throughout 2023
column23: which started the process of revaluing real estate in a higher interest rate environment
column24: but overall transaction volume was significantly lower than recent years as market participants
column25: including owners
column26: lenders
column27: potential buyers and sellers all chose to play for time and remain cautious in the face of an uncertain economic and interest rate environment.As we enter 2024
column28: there is increasing confidence in the Fed’s ability to engineer some type of soft landing and expectations of 100 to 150 bps of Fed rate cuts throughout the year. On the long end
column29: the 10-year is essentially exactly where it was at the beginning of 2023. And at present
column30: fears of that rate moving higher
column31: as it quickly did last year

column33: while there may be more optimism with respect to the economy and rates
column34: the narrative around commercial real estate continues to focus on further asset value degradation. There is still much to be done to address loan maturities and asset level capital structures in a higher rate environment in addition to the lingering uncertainty over the long-term use case for certain assets.Pivoting away from the value debate

column1: Despite shrinking by US$218m in the past week
column2: ATI (NYSE:ATI) shareholders are still up 127% over 3 years`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/despite-shrinking-us-218m-past-190217057.html`2024-01-31 19:02:17`The worst result
column3: after buying shares in a company (assuming no leverage)
column4: would be if you lose all the money you put in. But in contrast you can make much more than 100% if the company does well. For instance the ATI Inc. (NYSE:ATI) share price is 127% higher than it was three years ago. How nice for those who held the stock! On top of that
column5: the share price is up 11% in about a quarter. But this move may well have been assisted by the reasonably buoyant market (up 16% in 90 days).Since the long term performance has been good but there's been a recent pullback of 4.0%
column6: let's check if the fundamentals match the share price. Check out our latest analysis for ATI While markets are a powerful pricing mechanism
column7: share prices reflect investor sentiment
column8: not just underlying business performance. One flawed but reasonable way to assess how sentiment around a company has changed is to compare the earnings per share (EPS) with the share price.During three years of share price growth
column9: ATI moved from a loss to profitability. That kind of transition can be an inflection point that justifies a strong share price gain
column10: just as we have seen here.The image below shows how EPS has tracked over time (if you click on the image you can see greater detail).It is of course excellent to see how ATI has grown profits over the years
column11: but the future is more important for shareholders. You can see how its balance sheet has strengthened (or weakened) over time in this free interactive graphic.ATI shareholders gained a total return of 14% during the year. But that return falls short of the market. On the bright side
column12: that's still a gain
column13: and it's actually better than the average return of 8% over half a decade It is possible that returns will improve along with the business fundamentals. I find it very interesting to look at share price over the long term as a proxy for business performance. But to truly gain insight
column14: we need to consider other information
column15: too. Consider risks
column16: for instance. Every company has them
column17: and we've spotted   1 warning sign for ATI   you should know about.Of course
column18: you might find a fantastic investment by looking elsewhere. So take a peek at this free list of companies we expect will grow earnings.Please note
column19: the market returns quoted in this article reflect the market weighted average returns of stocks that currently trade on American exchanges.Have feedback on this article? Concerned about the content? Get in touch with us directly. Alternatively
column20: email editorial-team (at) simplywallst.com.This article by Simply Wall St is general in nature. We provide commentary based on historical data and analyst forecasts only using an unbiased methodology and our articles are not intended to be financial advice. It does not constitute a recommendation to buy or sell any stock
column21: and does not take account of your objectives
column22: or your financial situation. We aim to bring you long-term focused analysis driven by fundamental data. Note that our analysis may not factor in the latest price-sensitive company announcements or qualitative material. Simply Wall St has no position in any stocks mentioned.Related Quotes`['ATI']`

column4: Inc. (NASDAQ:AVPT) can tell us which group is most powerful. With 37% stake
column5: individual insiders possess the maximum shares in the company. Put another way
column6: the group faces the maximum upside potential (or downside risk).Despite recent sales
column7: insiders own the most shares in the company.Let's take a closer look to see what the different types of shareholders can tell us about AvePoint. View our latest analysis for AvePoint Institutions typically measure themselves against a benchmark when reporting to their own investors
column8: so they often become more enthusiastic about a stock once it's included in a major index. We would expect most companies to have some institutions on the register
column9: especially if they are growing.AvePoint already has institutions on the share registry. Indeed
column10: they own a respectable stake in the company. This suggests some credibility amongst professional investors. But we can't rely on that fact alone since institutions make bad investments sometimes
column11: just like everyone does. When multiple institutions own a stock
column12: there's always a risk that they are in a 'crowded trade'. When such a trade goes wrong
column13: multiple parties may compete to sell stock fast. This risk is higher in a company without a history of growth. You can see AvePoint's historic earnings and revenue below
column14: but keep in mind there's always more to the story.We note that hedge funds don't have a meaningful investment in AvePoint. Zhijian Lu is currently the company's largest shareholder with 10% of shares outstanding. For context
column15: the second largest shareholder holds about 9.5% of the shares outstanding
column16: followed by an ownership of 9.1% by the third-largest shareholder. Xunkai Gong
column17: who is the second-largest shareholder
column18: also happens to hold the title of Top Key Executive. Additionally
column19: the company's CEO Tianyi Jiang directly holds 8.6% of the total shares outstanding.On further inspection
column20: we found that more than half the company's shares are owned by the top 6 shareholders
column21: suggesting that the interests of the larger shareholders are balanced out to an extent by the smaller ones.While it makes sense to study institutional ownership data for a company
column22: it also makes sense to study analyst sentiments to know which way the wind is blowing. Quite a few analysts cover the stock
column23: so you could look into forecast growth quite easily.The definition of an insider can differ slightly between different countries
column24: but members of the board of directors always count. The company management answer to the board and the latter should represent the interests of shareholders. Notably
column25: sometimes top-level managers are on the board themselves.Most consider insider ownership a positive because it can indicate the board is well aligned with other shareholders. However
column26: on some occasions too much power is concentrated within this group.It seems insiders own a significant proportion of AvePoint

column1: Institutional investors are American Express Company's (NYSE:AXP) biggest bettors and were rewarded after last week's US$5.8b market cap gain`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/institutional-investors-american-express-companys-110013005.html`2024-02-09 11:00:13`Significantly high institutional ownership implies American Express' stock price is sensitive to their trading actionsA total of 12 investors have a majority stake in the company with 50% ownership Recent sales by insiders If you want to know who really controls American Express Company (NYSE:AXP)
column2: then you'll have to look at the makeup of its share registry. We can see that institutions own the lion's share in the company with 65% ownership. That is
column3: the group stands to benefit the most if the stock rises (or lose the most if there is a downturn).And last week
column4: institutional investors ended up benefitting the most after the company hit US$151b in market cap. The gains from last week would have further boosted the one-year return to shareholders which currently stand at 19%.In the chart below
column5: we zoom in on the different ownership groups of American Express. See our latest analysis for American Express Institutional investors commonly compare their own returns to the returns of a commonly followed index. So they generally do consider buying larger companies that are included in the relevant benchmark index.As you can see
column6: institutional investors have a fair amount of stake in American Express. This can indicate that the company has a certain degree of credibility in the investment community. However
column7: it is best to be wary of relying on the supposed validation that comes with institutional investors. They too
column8: get it wrong sometimes. When multiple institutions own a stock
column9: there's always a risk that they are in a 'crowded trade'. When such a trade goes wrong
column10: multiple parties may compete to sell stock fast. This risk is higher in a company without a history of growth. You can see American Express' historic earnings and revenue below
column11: but keep in mind there's always more to the story.Investors should note that institutions actually own more than half the company
column12: so they can collectively wield significant power. American Express is not owned by hedge funds. Our data shows that Berkshire Hathaway Inc. is the largest shareholder with 21% of shares outstanding. In comparison
column13: the second and third largest shareholders hold about 6.5% and 6.1% of the stock.After doing some more digging
column14: we found that the top 12 have the combined ownership of 50% in the company
column15: suggesting that no single shareholder has significant control over the company.Researching institutional ownership is a good way to gauge and filter a stock's expected performance. The same can be achieved by studying analyst sentiments. Quite a few analysts cover the stock
column16: so you could look into forecast growth quite easily.The definition of company insiders can be subjective and does vary between jurisdictions. Our data reflects individual insiders
column17: capturing board members at the very least. Management ultimately answers to the board. However
column18: it is not uncommon for managers to be executive board members
column19: especially if they are a founder or the CEO.I generally consider insider ownership to be a good thing. However
column20: on some occasions it makes it more difficult for other shareholders to hold the board accountable for decisions.Our most recent data indicates that insiders own less than 1% of American Express Company. It is a very large company
column21: so it would be surprising to see insiders own a large proportion of the company. Though their holding amounts to less than 1%
column22: we can see that board members collectively own US$223m worth of shares (at current prices). In this sort of situation
column23: it can be more interesting to  see if those insiders have been buying or selling. The general public-- including retail investors -- own 14% stake in the company
column24: and hence can't easily be ignored. While this group can't necessarily call the shots
column25: it can certainly have a real influence on how the company is run.Public companies currently own 21% of American Express stock. We can't be certain but it is quite possible this is a strategic stake. The businesses may be similar
column26: or work together.I find it very interesting to look at who exactly owns a company. But to truly gain insight
column27: we need to consider other information
column28: too. Take risks for example - American Express has   1 warning sign   we think you should be aware of.But ultimately  it is the future
column29: not the past
column30: that will determine how well the owners of this business will do. Therefore we think it advisable to take a look at this free report showing whether analysts are predicting a brighter future.NB: Figures in this article are calculated using data from the last twelve months

Capital Investments At AutoZone (NYSE:AZO) Point To A Promising Future`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/capital-investments-autozone-nyse-azo-130019265.html`2024-02-08 13:00:19`What trends should we look for it we want to identify stocks that can multiply in value over the long term? Amongst other things
column2: we'll want to see two things; firstly
column3: a growing return on capital employed (ROCE) and secondly
column4: an expansion in the company's amount of capital employed. Ultimately
column5: this demonstrates that it's a business that is reinvesting profits at increasing rates of return. Ergo
column6: when we looked at the ROCE trends at AutoZone (NYSE:AZO)
column7: we liked what we saw.Just to clarify if you're unsure
column8: ROCE is a metric for evaluating how much pre-tax income (in percentage terms) a company earns on the capital invested in its business. The formula for this calculation on AutoZone is:Return on Capital Employed = Earnings Before Interest and Tax (EBIT) ÷ (Total Assets - Current Liabilities)0.48 = US$3.6b ÷ (US$16b - US$8.8b) (Based on the trailing twelve months to November 2023).Thus
column9: AutoZone has an ROCE of 48%.  That's a fantastic return and not only that
column10: it outpaces the average of 12% earned by companies in a similar industry. View our latest analysis for AutoZone In the above chart we have measured AutoZone's prior ROCE against its prior performance
column11: but the future is arguably more important. If you'd like
column12: you can check out the forecasts from the analysts covering AutoZone here  for free.AutoZone deserves to be commended in regards to it's returns. The company has consistently earned 48% for the last five years
column13: and the capital employed within the business has risen 72% in that time. Returns like this are the envy of most businesses and given it has repeatedly reinvested at these rates
column14: that's even better. You'll see this when looking at well operated businesses or favorable business models.On a side note
column15: AutoZone's current liabilities are still rather high at 54% of total assets. This effectively means that suppliers (or short-term creditors) are funding a large portion of the business
column16: so just be aware that this can introduce some elements of risk. Ideally we'd like to see this reduce as that would mean fewer obligations bearing risks.In the end
column17: the company has proven it can reinvest it's capital at high rates of returns
column18: which you'll remember is a trait of a multi-bagger. And long term investors would be thrilled with the 219% return they've received over the last five years. So while investors seem to be recognizing these promising trends
column19: we still believe the stock deserves further research.If you'd like to know more about AutoZone
column20: we've spotted   4 warning signs
column21: and 2 of them are a bit unpleasant.If you want to search for more stocks that have been earning high returns

13 Best Aerospace and Defense Stocks to Invest In`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/13-best-aerospace-defense-stocks-113953867.html`2024-02-10 11:39:53`In this piece
column2: we will take a look at the 13 best aerospace and defense stocks to invest in. If you want to skip our overview of the high technology aerospace and defense industry and how it's shaped the modern day world
column3: you can take a look at the 5 Best Aerospace and Defense Stocks to Invest In. If there's one thing that can be said with certainty
column4: it's that the defense and aerospace industry is one of the most important in the world when it comes to shaping power politics. Global geopolitics
column5: and as the late Henry Kissinger would describe
column6: 'realpolitik' is based on the cold
column7: hard reality of military superiority. Traditionally
column8: this superiority came in the form of strength in numbers - a concept that still holds true today.However
column9: along with this
column10: another concept that has borne the test of time is the use of technology for warfare. Whether it's the Mongols who relied on brutal cavalry tactics
column11: or the Ottoman use of gunpowder that made it a 'gunpowder empire'
column12: technology has shaped warfare and global power dynamics.These days
column13: the dominant and only superpower (some would even say a hyperpower) is the United States of America. The U.S.
column14: if you're unaware
column15: has the most powerful military in the world
column16: fueled by the greatest number of aircraft carriers for any military and an air force whose aircraft number in the thousands. Safe to say
column17: aerospace plays a crucial role in maintaining American global military superiority
column18: and by effect
column19: it also shapes the global world order.Powering the U.S. military behemoth
column20: which also has the biggest defense budget in the world
column21: are aerospace and defense stocks. These stocks are firms that either directly engage in providing the U.S. military
column22: through the Department of Defense
column23: with their combat or combat support equipment
column24: or those that provide essential and tertiary capabilities such as the defense stock Planet Labs PBC (NYSE:PL) and Maxar Technologies whose advanced satellites carry the ability to remotely image any site in the world and provide military planners with invaluable information to inform their tactical and strategic decisions.Technology sits at the heart of competing when it comes to defense and aerospace stocks
column25: and a technological edge is precisely the reason that the U.S. is at the top of the global power food chain. American jets are envied by dictators and monarchs all over the world
column26: and no matter what their public statements against the U.S. are
column27: it wouldn't be imprudent to assume that they would give an arm and a leg (and then some) to get a taste of what American defense and aerospace stocks have to offer.So what exactly do they offer? Well
column28: let's start with one of the most well known defense and aerospace stocks in the world
column29: the Bethesda
column30: Maryland based aerospace firm Lockheed Martin Corporation (NYSE:LMT). Lockheed
column31: if you're unaware
column32: makes and sells fighter aircraft. While it also has other divisions
column33: such as a space segment that aims to develop a colony on the Moon complete with a nuclear reactor in partnership with the National Aerospace and Space Administration (NASA)
column34: Lockheed Martin's bread and butter are airplanes. The firm in its current form came into being in the late 1990s as the U.S. defense industry consolidated (more on that later). Lockheed merged with Martin Marietta in 1995
column35: after it acquired General Dynamics - perhaps one of the most consequential defense and aerospace stocks in the world.That's a tall claim. So what made Martin Marietta so special? Well
column36: the firm bought General Dynamics in 1993 -  a deal that also saw it acquire the rights to the General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon. The F-16 is the most successful fighter aircraft in the world and is used by most of the world's leading air forces. Its success has defined modern day dog fighting - an art that bulky fighter jets such as the The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA)'s F-15 struggled with.Lockheed has moved past dog fighting since then. For aerospace and defense stocks
column37: the 21st century has been all about stealth. Lockheed's F-117 'Nighthawk' and the technologies used on it dominated the stealth debate for decades
column38: and led to the development of the world's only operational fifth generation fighter aircraft
column39: the F-22 'Raptor'. America's crown jewel
column40: the Raptor is an air superiority fighter designed with the singular aim of ensuring that enemy fighters cannot contest the United States Air Force's control of an airspace.So
column41: as aerospace and defense stocks continue to make magic a reality
column42: we decided to take a look at some top stocks. Among these
column43: the notable ones are The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA)
column44: TransDigm Group Incorporated (NYSE:TDG)
column45: and RTX Corporation (NYSE:RTX).Andrey Khachatryan/Shutterstock.comOur Methodology To make our list of the best aerospace and defense stocks
column46: we ranked the 40 most valuable aerospace and defense stocks that trade in U.S. markets by the number of hedge funds that had bought their shares in Q3 2023. Out of these
column47: the top stocks were chosen.For these aerospace and defense stocks
column48: we used hedge fund sentiment. Hedge funds’ top 10 consensus stock picks outperformed the S&P 500 Index by more than 140 percentage points over the last 10 years (see the details here). That’s why we pay very close attention to this often-ignored indicator.Number of Q3 2023 Hedge Fund Shareholders: 27 Textron Inc. (NYSE:TXT) is a diversified aviation defense stock that sells crewed and uncrewed aircraft for military use. The firm has been doing well on the financial front as of late since it has beaten analyst EPS estimates in all four of its latest quarters.By the end of last year's third quarter

Gol Accuses Latam Airlines of Attempting to Poach Pilots
column2: Aircraft`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/gol-accuses-latam-airlines-attempting-201716440.html`2024-02-09 21:35:43`(Bloomberg) -- Bankrupt Brazilian airline Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA accused its rival Latam Airlines Group SA of taking advantage of its recent financial trouble by trying to poach its pilots and Boeing aircraft.Most Read from BloombergGermany’s Days as an Industrial Superpower Are Coming to an EndBiden’s Attempt to Address Memory Issue Backfires With New GaffeTop Nigerian Banker Killed in Helicopter Crash in CaliforniaBezos Sells $2 Billion of Amazon Shares in First Major Stock Sale Since 2021Putin Showed Carlson Why He Really Invaded UkraineThe Sao Paulo-based airline said in court papers filed Thursday that Latam recently sent a letter to Gol’s business partners inquiring about leasing Boeing aircraft and solicited Brazilian pilots experienced in flying such aircraft in an Internet job posting. Latam has historically flown a fleet of Airbus aircraft and the Boeing models its competitor inquired about are a specific type of narrow body aircraft Gol flies
column3: the filing said.The Brazilian airline said Latam inquired about procuring Boeing 737 aircraft the day after Gol filed Chapter 11 on Jan. 25
column4: while its rival “is at its most vulnerable.” Gol asked Judge Martin Glenn
column5: who is overseeing the bankruptcy
column6: for permission to issue a subpoena for documents from Latam as it investigates the scope of the alleged solicitations.“Given the recent events in the industry
column7: we thought you may be interested in learning that LATAM group continues to seek aircraft
column8: ” Latam allegedly said in a letter sent to its business partners on Jan. 26. The letter
column9: a copy of which is included in Thursday’s court filing
column10: goes on to say that Latam’s Brazilian affiliate is seeking to increase its flights in the country and region.Gol said it believes Latam is trying to interfere with its business and that its rival may have violated the Brazilian airline’s automatic bankruptcy stay which protects companies in Chapter 11.Latam has denied Gol’s allegations.Latam said Friday the company is in the market for so-called narrow body aircraft because there are supply chain problems impacting the availability of Airbus and Boeing aircraft. The company said it does fly some Boeing aircraft and flew Boeing 737 aircraft up until 2014. Even though Gol exclusively uses Boeing 737 aircraft
column11: Latam said
column12: “the Debtors operate just a fraction of the overall market for these incredibly popular planes.”In emails with Gol’s attorneys included in Thursday’s filing
column13: Latam lawyer Brian Shaughnessy said “GOL’s accusations against LATAM are completely wrong and
column14: frankly
column15: frivolous
column16: as well as inconsistent with well-established jurisprudence.” In a Feb. 6 email to Gol’s lawyers
column17: Shaughnessy wrote “From our perspective
column18: it is GOL who is trying to interfere with LATAM’s business.”Gol has already won approval from Judge Glenn to start drawing on a $950 million Chapter 11 loan provided by lenders including Elliott Investment Management LP. The airline is one of the largest in South America but has struggled with financial liabilities it incurred by the drop in travel during the pandemic
column19: substantial debt and Brazil’s high interest rates.The case is GOL Linhas Aereas Inteligentes SA
column21: US Bankruptcy Court
column22: Southern District of New York (Manhattan).(Updates to include details on Latam’s Friday court filing)Most Read from Bloomberg BusinessweekOpenAI’s Secret Weapon Is Sam Altman’s 33-Year-Old LieutenantHow Jack Dorsey’s Plan to Get Elon Musk to Save Twitter Went SouthIt’s Time to Talk About Those Taylor Swift Super Bowl BetsInside a Private Jet Club Where Everything Went WrongA Tiny Fund Takes a Big Short on Corporate Debt Maturity Wall©2024 Bloomberg L.P.Related Quotes`['GOLLQ'

column1: The CEO of Europe’s largest airline is about to trigger a $108 million bonus that British shareholders can’t vote on because of Brexit`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/ceo-europe-largest-airline-trigger-195711304.html`2024-02-09 19:57:11`Ryanair CEO Michael O’Leary could be in for a €100 million ($108 million) payday if the airline’s stock continues on its current trajectory.The Dublin-based carrier’s shares currently sit at €20.11 each. Should the stock reach €21 and stay there for 28 consecutive days
column2: O’Leary would be eligible for stock options valued at €100 million ($108 million). But that has some analysts from Barclays worried—and British shareholders won’t even get a say on the pay package for the leader of Europe’s largest airline.As with most major bonus payouts to executives
column3: shareholders get the opportunity to vote on whether to approve the payment. However
column4: because of financial regulations imposed since Brexit
column5: shareholders in the U.K. won’t get the chance to do so. Barclays analysts said the fact that not all shareholders will get to vote on the pay package presents a corporate governance risk.O’Leary already owns about 3.9% of the company
column6: a stake valued at around $978 million.Ryanair and Barclays did not respond to requests for comment.O’Leary himself
column7: for what it’s worth
column8: has been a staunch critic of Brexit. As far back as 2018
column9: O’Leary warned that complying with the EU’s laws overseeing airlines would be extremely difficult and that he could see flights between the U.K. and the continent grounded. When the U.K.’s economy struggled in late 2022 he blamed it on Brexit
column10: which he called a “car crash.” In his usual colorful style O’Leary opined that the U.K. would eventually rejoin the EU once all the “delusional” Brexiteers died.As a result of Brexit
column11: Ryanair implemented a new corporate policy in December 2020 that would restrict U.K. shareholders from voting on corporate matters. The rules were adopted to comply with EU regulations that require airlines from countries within the bloc be majority owned by EU nationals. U.K. shareholders had their existing shares turned into restricted shares that didn’t allow them to vote on governance issues. U.K. nationals were then banned from buying stock in the company
column12: though they are allowed to purchase a different class of shares called American depositary receipts that are available on the Nasdaq. In 2021
column13: when some U.K. investors violated those regulations
column14: Ryanair forced them to sell their shares via an independent broker.That
column15: in addition to the fact that executives have signaled they are open to using a portion of the company’s available cash for stock buybacks
column16: raises governance concerns
column17: according to Barclays analysts.“This would add further corporate governance complexity
column18: ” wrote Andrew Lobbenberg
column19: the head of equity research for the European transportation sector at Barclays.In November
column20: Ryanair announced its first-ever dividend of roughly $430 million. The stock rose 8% on the back of that announcement.In order for O’Leary to earn the bonus payment
column21: Ryanair will also have to see net profits of €2.2 billion
column22: which analysts expect to happen. Ryanair has cut its profit forecast for 2023
column23: saying it had to lower prices to keep planes full for various reasons
column24: including the Boeing disaster with Alaska Airlines.O’Leary has been the chief executive of Ryanair since 1994 and is considered to be the executive that powered the budget airline to such a prominent status in Europe. To consumers
column25: Ryanair is known for its cheap flights across the continent. For example
column26: a flight from London to Berlin costs just $25 dollars. To shareholders
column27: O’Leary is known for delivering meaningful gains as he’s driven the stock price up 28% over the past 12 months. He also successfully steered the company out of the pandemic-induced travel slump that plagued airlines in 2020 and early 2021. O’Leary has brought Ryanair’s stock up 137% since it plummeted to its low of €8.45 in May 2020.The case for why Ryanair’s strong performance might not continue hinges on its relationship with Boeing. The aircraft manufacturer was slated to deliver 57 737 Max planes to Ryanair this summer. Ten of those planes were reportedly already going to be late. Now
column28: the rest of the order could be in jeopardy as well
column29: as Boeing contends with the fallout from its recent maintenance disaster when the door of a plane blew off mid-flight at roughly 16
column30: 000 feet. Shortly after that incident O’Leary reiterated his commitment to Boeing
column31: saying he would be happy to purchase leftover aircraft if other airlines canceled their orders. That wasn’t without chastising Boeing publicly for ignoring what he said were repeated warnings over two years to address maintenance issues. O’Leary later said he wasn’t sure if the Federal Aviation Administration’s investigation into Boeing would delay Ryanair’s order.This story was originally featured on Fortune.comRelated Quotes`['RYAAY'

column1: Analysis-Boeing strikes conciliatory tone with suppliers amid 737 MAX crisis`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/analysis-boeing-strikes-conciliatory-tone-163747086.html`2024-02-09 16:37:47`"By Valerie InsinnaSEATTLE (Reuters) - Boeing executives extended an olive branch to the company's strained supply chain this week to help them deal with the fallout of the latest 737 MAX crisis
column2: but those firms are taking a wait-and-see attitude after years of dealing with the planemaker's hard-line approach.The aerospace giant's shift in tone was underlined by a speech on Wednesday by Ihssane Mounir
column3: Boeing's vice president of supply chain and fabrication
column4: at an aerospace conference outside Seattle. ""We build the airplane together. There's no you and us. It's just us
column5: he said.Mounir's remarks - and those of Boeing's head of supplier quality on Tuesday - were the first public addresses by Boeing to its base of more than 1
column6: 100 suppliers in the Pacific Northwest region after a Jan. 5 mid-air blowout on a Boeing 737 MAX 9 that has rocked the aerospace industry.Multiple suppliers who spoke to Reuters on the condition of anonymity said Mounir's comments marked a shift in tone from Boeing's previous strategy for driving supply-chain efficiency and cost-reduction
column7: exemplified by the company's notorious ""Partnering for Success"" initiative in the 2010s.The initiative
column8: which cut supply-chain costs by 15%
column9: was unpopular with suppliers who said Boeing had profited on the backs of a squeezed industrial base. The planemaker has said in the past that the program was necessary to assure the company's long-term competitive advantage.One supplier said this week that they were ""cautiously optimistic
column10: but added that Boeing must demonstrate its willingness to give under-pressure suppliers enough time to ensure products are properly manufactured and inspected.Two other suppliers were skeptical
column11: saying that Boeing would need to prove Mounir's comments were more than lip service.Mounir's remarks marked a return by Boeing to the Pacific Northwest Aerospace Alliance conference after a two-year absence.Boeing declined to comment.THE 'NEW NORMAL'Boeing is under fire from regulators and lawmakers after the MAX 9 accident near Portland
column12: Oregon. The Federal Aviation Administration is now blocking further production increases of the company's bestselling 737 MAX. The planemaker has said it is producing 38 737s per month.The cap on 737 MAX production hit at a time when airline demand for new planes is at an all-time high and the supply chain is still struggling with the reverberations of COVID-19 that prompted an exodus of experienced workers and led to materials shortages.Boeing has told 737 suppliers to carry on with planned production rate hikes to try to mitigate financial distress to small and midsized businesses
column13: many of which have hired workers and invested in new equipment.Instead of talk about cost-cutting and speeding up production - common during the ""Partnering for Success"" era - Mounir repeatedly emphasized that Boeing and its supply chain must work together to ensure manufacturing standards are followed and quality is uncompromised.Mounir acknowledged ""a lot of tribal knowledge"" had been lost during the pandemic
column14: urging suppliers to join a recently launched forum where companies can share best practices.He told suppliers to speak up and said Boeing was committed to providing assistance to vulnerable companies
column15: including obtaining raw materials
column16: engineering help or financial relief.Analysts said Boeing may have no choice but to take suppliers' concerns more seriously
column17: as the dwindling supply base leaves planemakers with few other options.Suppliers have yet to understand that a ""new normal"" has emerged where they have more leverage than ever to ask for beneficial contract terms
column18: such as long-term agreements and better inflation pricing adjustments
column19: Morgan Stanley analyst Kristine Liwag said during the conference.""You now have the strategic power in the relationship
column20: she said.(Reporting by Valerie Insinna in Seattle; Editing by Matthew Lewis)Related Quotes"`['BA']`

column2: Health Savings Account Balances Increased by 11%`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/bofa-report-finds-401-k-130000288.html`2024-02-07 13:00:00`"Percentage of Plan Participants Who Increased Their 401(k) Contribution Rate Doubled in Q4 CHARLOTTE
column3: N.C.
column4: Feb. 7
column5: 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Today
column6: Bank of America Retirement and Personal Wealth Solutions
column7: in partnership with Bank of America Institute
column8: released its fourth quarter 2023 Participant Pulse (MAP6212241)
column9: which found that average 401(k) account balances rose 15% to $86
column11: increasing from $75
column12: 045 at the end of 2022
column13: due to a combination of participants contributing higher amounts to their plans
column14: and increases in the value of investments.1 Nearly 18% of 401(k) plan participants increased their contribution rates last quarter
column15: up from just over 9% who did so in the third quarter.2 In addition
column16: year-end 2023 Health Savings Account balances increased 11% over the prior year.3The Pulse monitors the behavior of plan participants in Bank of America recordkeeping clients' employee benefits programs
column17: which are comprised of more than 4 million participants as of December 31
column18: 2023.""We were encouraged to see more plan participants taking positive actions in their accounts in the fourth quarter
column19: said Lorna Sabbia
column20: Head of Retirement and Personal Wealth Solutions at Bank of America. ""These insights offer signs that people are prioritizing their retirement savings
column21: with more employees increasing their contribution rates and fewer taking hardship distributions.""The report found that fewer participants borrowed from their 401(k) plan (2.3%
column22: down from 2.5% in the third quarter)
column23: and the average loan per participant declined to $8
column24: 210 (down from $8
column25: 530).2Health Saving Account TrendsIn addition to 401(k) trends
column26: the Participant Pulse examines engagement across Health Saving Accounts (HSA) and overall feelings of financial wellness. Key findings include:Average HSA account balance increased by 11% YoY. Average account balances increased to $4
column28: up from $3
column29: 930 at year-end 2022
column30: with nearly 4-in-10 accountholders contributing more than they withdrew.3Millennials saved more of their HSAs. Overall
column31: 76% of HSA contributions were spent on health care expenses
column32: while 24% were saved. Millennials4 saved 34% of their contributions
column33: more than any other generation.3More men than women invested their HSA contributions. 12% of account holders invested their HSA contributions for future growth
column34: with men outpacing women (17% vs. 11%).3Read the full report and methodology here to learn more.1Comparisons to 2022 reference data derived from Bank of America Retirement and Benefit Plan Services 401(k) data platform as of 12/31/2022.2Comparisons to 2023 Q3 reference data derived from Bank of America Retirement and Benefit Plan Services 401(k) data platform as of 9/30/2023.3Reference data derived from Bank of America Retirement and Benefit Plan Services HSA data platform as of 12/31/2023.4Generation defined by the following birth years: Baby Boomers 1946 – 1964; Gen X 1965 – 1980; Millennials 1981 – 2000

column1: RBA Keeps Rate at 12-Year High
column2: Signals Higher Bar for Rate Hikes`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/rba-keeps-rate-12-high-033520613.html`2024-02-06 06:31:16`(Bloomberg) -- Australia’s central bank left interest rates at a 12-year high and signaled further tightening remains possible
column3: joining global peers in pushing back against expectations for near-term easing and sending the currency and bond yields higher.Most Read from BloombergKing Charles Treated for Cancer in New Royal Health ScareWhy NYC Apartment Buildings Are on Sale Now for 50% OffChina Tightens Some Trading Restrictions for Domestic and Offshore InvestorsXi to Discuss China Stocks With Regulators as Rescue Bets BuildEastern Europe’s Richest Woman Pivots $43 Billion Empire WestThe Reserve Bank maintained its cash rate at 4.35% — as predicted by economists — on Tuesday
column4: and said in a post-meeting statement that “a further increase in interest rates cannot be ruled out.”At her inaugural conference following the rate decision
column5: RBA Governor Michele Bullock reiterated the board’s hawkish stance as she emphasized that inflation remained “too high.” The messaging prompted the currency to rise against all its major peers and swaps traders to bet the RBA will trail counterparts from the Federal Reserve to the Bank of England in policy easing this year.“We are not ruling in anything or out anything
column6: ” Bullock said. She signaled that taming inflation was taking priority over the desire to provide relief to heavily-indebted mortgage holders
column7: saying “we need to stay the course.”The governor defended the RBA’s surprise November interest-rate hike
column8: noting it was needed to guard against upside risks to inflation. Risks now appear “fairly balanced
column9: ” she said.The Australian dollar rose as much as 0.5% to 65.17 US cents
column10: while yields on policy sensitive three-year government bonds were up 2 basis points to 3.70%. Swaps traders now see the chance of a June rate cut at 42% from about 50% beforehand
column11: according to data compiled by Bloomberg.The RBA “retains a mild tightening bias in contrast to the Fed
column12: BoC
column13: ECB and BoE
column14: ” said Su-Lin Ong
column15: chief economist at Royal Bank of Canada
column16: adding the statement was “more hawkish” than markets expected.“The language around inflation is strong despite downward revisions.”The RBA also released its quarterly forecasts which showed core inflation will only hit the midpoint of its 2-3% target band in 2026. The trimmed mean measure
column17: which smooths volatile items
column18: came in at 4.2% in the final three months of 2023.Read more: RBA Sees Inflation Hitting 2.5% Target Mid-Point in 2026The extended timeframe for inflation to return to target suggests the RBA will stick to its view that rates need to remain at elevated levels for some time
column19: according to money markets and economists. That suggests Australia may be one of the last dollar-bloc economies to begin easing
column20: they said.Underlining that
column21: rates traders expect the RBA to hold off policy easing until later in the year
column22: while they are certain the Fed will begin cuts by June. Australia’s central bank is seen as likely to undertake two quarter-point reductions this year
column23: while the Fed is seen delivering as many as five.“Maintaining a tightening bias signals to the fiscal authorities that it’s too early to declare the inflation fight over
column24: ” said Gareth Aird
column25: head of Australia economics at Commonwealth Bank of Australia. “The RBA would not wish to see fiscal settings loosened until further progress on inflation has been made towards the target band.”Reinforcing that theme
column26: Bullock noted in her press conference that Australian governments are “keenly aware” of inflation risks.Fed Chair Jerome Powell said Americans may have to wait beyond March for the central bank to cut rates as officials look for more economic data to confirm that inflation is headed down to 2%. In an interview with CBS’s 60 Minutes that aired Sunday evening
column27: Powell said the “danger of moving too soon is that the job’s not quite done.”Bullock did not provide a timeline on the RBA’s next moves in either direction
column28: saying optionality on rates is needed as the board remains squarely data-dependent.What Bloomberg Economics Says...“We think the evolution of inflation
column29: demand and the labor market over coming months will lead the RBA to not only pivot to neutral
column30: but to begin cutting rates as soon as May.”— James McIntyre
column31: economist— For the full note
column32: click hereThe RBA moved cautiously during its tightening campaign — its 4.25 percentage points of hikes was 1 point less than the US and New Zealand delivered. Another reason for expectations the RBA will be slower on the way down is the disinflation impulse so far in Australia is weaker than elsewhere
column33: with productivity growth among the weakest in the developed world.At the same time
column34: Australia’s labor market remains solid and the economy has shown resilience to higher borrowing costs
column35: suggesting there’s no urgency to shift quickly to easing. Moreover
column36: policymakers won’t want to further fuel house prices that have been driven up by a supply shortage and high immigration.“We do not expect any further rate increases by the RBA this cycle
column37: ” said Luci Ellis
column38: chief economist at Westpac Banking Corp. and a former RBA official. “Rate cuts are still some way off
column39: though. The RBA board will need to be sufficiently comfortable that inflation will definitely decline into the 2–3% target band.”--With assistance from Garfield Reynolds.(Adds comments from press conference from third paragraph)Most Read from Bloomberg BusinessweekBloomberg New Economy Is Looking for World-Changing Leaders A Brutal Crime Crackdown Is Emboldening Leaders Across Latin AmericaIs It Morning in Joe Biden’s America?Elon Musk May Have Lost More Than a $55 Billion PaydayMano dura de El Salvador contra el crimen seduce a América Latina©2024 Bloomberg L.P.Related Quotes`['AGKSWG.AX'

column1: Commercial real estate a 'manageable' problem but some banks will close: Powell`https://finance.yahoo.com/news/commercial-real-estate-a-manageable-problem-but-some-banks-will-close-powell-161201936.html`2024-02-05 16:12:01`"Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is predicting that more small banks will likely close or merge due to commercial real estate weaknesses
column2: but that the problem is ultimately ""manageable.""The central bank official made this point during a ""60 Minutes"" interview that aired Sunday night. It was Powell’s first comments about the industry following a new bout of turmoil cascading through the stocks of many regional banks.""I don't think there's much risk of a repeat of 2008
column3: Powell said
column4: referring to a financial crisis 16 years ago that took down some of the biggest institutions on Wall Street as well as hundreds of banks across the US.""I do think it’s a manageable problem
column5: he added.The new concerns about regional banks were triggered by $116 billion commercial real estate lender New York Community Bancorp (NYCB)
column6: which shocked Wall Street last Wednesday when it slashed its dividend
column7: reported a surprise quarterly loss
column8: and stockpiled millions for future loan losses related to commercial real estate holdings.The stock of the Hicksville
column9: N.Y.-based lender fell 38% on Wednesday and another 11% on Thursday
column10: dragging the rest of the sector down with it. The stocks recovered Friday but dropped once again on Monday as New York Community Bancorp fell more than 10%.Powell acknowledged in his ""60 Minutes"" interview that some smaller banks will ""have to be closed"" or merged ""out of existence"" due to losses tied to the falling values of properties across the US that are suddenly worth much less due to the Fed’s elevated interest rates and the effect of a pandemic that emptied out many city-center buildings.But ""we looked at the larger banks' balance sheets
column11: and it appears to be a manageable problem
column12: Powell said.""There's some smaller and regional banks that have concentrated exposures in these areas that are challenged. And
column13: you know
column14: we're working with them. This is something we've been aware of for
column15: you know
column16: a long time
column17: and we're working with them to make sure that they have the resources and a plan to work their way through the expected losses.""Regional banks are particularly vulnerable because they hold a lot more exposure to these properties than larger rivals. For banks with more than $100 billion in assets
column18: commercial real estate loans only account for 13% of total credit. For smaller banks
column19: they account for 44% of total bank credit.Loans tied to offices and certain multifamily housing properties are showing the most weakness. Not all segments of commercial real estate are expected to face the same problems.Demand for commercial real estate loans from US banks
column20: meanwhile
column21: weakened in the fourth quarter of 2023 as bank officers tightened their standards
column22: according to a new Fed report released Monday. These officers expect standards to stay tight in 2024 on all loan categories except for residential real estate.David Chiaverini
column23: a regional and midsized bank analyst for Wedbush Securities
column24: told Yahoo Finance that commercial real estate ""will be managed better at some of the other banks"" than at New York Community Bancorp
column25: which also has a high level of exposure to rent-controlled apartment complexes in New York City. Those buildings account for 22% of its loans.Chiaverini said the bank should have set aside more in reserves last year while booking a gain from its purchase of assets from the failed Signature Bank.""The severity of the issue is
column26: I would say
column27: mostly idiosyncratic to New York Community Bank because they were so under-reserved relative to the risk in their portfolio
column28: he added.The ""perfect storm"" that could create problems for the rest of the industry
column29: according to Chiaverini
column30: is if inflation goes back up
column31: forcing the Fed to keep rates higher for longer
column32: and the US economy enters a recession. Borrowers would then have problems keeping up with their loans.If those things don’t happen
column33: the commercial real estate pain should be ""manageable"" for the banks
column34: he added.The Fed chair repeated that same word three times in his ""60 Minutes"" interview.""It should be manageable
column35: Powell said.David Hollerith is a senior reporter for Yahoo Finance covering banking
column36: crypto
column37: and other areas in finance.Click here for in-depth analysis of the latest stock market news and events moving stock prices.Read the latest financial and business news from Yahoo FinanceRelated Quotes"`['BAC'
